div.p: MANAGEMENT: A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.
AT PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.
LONDON: Printed by A. Strahan, Printers Street; FOR T. • . LONGMAN AND O. REES, PATERNOSTER-ROW.

sp.l: A Well-known Muſe, who labours once a-year,
And oft has found a ſafe Aſylum here,
Though Critic ſtorms a Mother's fears excite,
With her new Offspring ventures forth to-night.
Conſcious the features muſt betray the Sire,
She ſeeks for no diſguiſe of vain attire;
What honeſt Nature gave ſhe brings to view,
And for a kind adoption reſts on you.
Yet haply now with reaſon ſhe appears
Oppreſs'd with more than e'en maternal fears.
For ſince ſhe laſt enjoy'd your foſt'ring ſmile,
A German Rival's charms have caught our Iſle.
And though ſhe knows that Rival's favor'd race,
With daring force combine a ſoft'ning grace,
She knows, beſides, that one of native breed
May always hope with Britons to ſucceed:
And hence, though faſhion call her bigot-ſool,
She takes no leſſons from a foreign ſchool—
But with a patriot pride ſhe lets you know,
"'Tis Engliſh! Engliſh, Sirs! from top to toe!"
While on your liberal candour we rely,
And Faſhion's rage with patriot zeal defy,
Think not our Author ſees with jealous pain
Exotic merit Britiſh laurels gain—
No—when to ALBION'S hoſpitable ſhore
MISFORTUNE flies protection to implore;
Or GENIUS darting from a diſtant ſphere,
That mental Comet ſpreads its radiance here;
May Britons glow with philanthropic fire,
Eager alike to cheriſh and admire!

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE—A View of Sutherland-houſe, Park, Gardens, &c.
div.stage: Enter GEOFFRY and two other Servants.

sp.speaker: GEOFFRY.
sp.p: COME, buſtle, buſtle—all to your ſeveral occupations.—Bleſs me, who'd have thought of Sir Hervey coming home:—go—enter the houſe, and prepare for his reception—I'll wait his arrival here.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Good morning, good old Geoffry.— I have once more eluded the vigilance of my perſecutor—once more ſtolen forth from the caſtle, purpoſely to viſit this ſpot; and if my father hears of it, I hope he won't be angry with me:—though he denies me his protection, ſurely he will not preclude me from contemplating ſcenes that remind me of him and my dear Mother!—why, what's the matter? you ſeem agitated.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p:
Well I may, Miſs Juliana—your father
is arrived from Italy, and I expect him here this very day.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Expect my father!

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Ay; after an abſence of thirteen years, I expect Sir Hervey once more at Sutherland-houſe: —look, here's his letter.

sp.speaker: Juliana
sp.stage: (ſnatching the letter, reading and kiſſing it).
sp.p: Oh, I'm ſo happy!—I ſhall at laſt behold, perhaps embrace him.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Nay, I fear otherwiſe; Sir Hervey is of a moſt unforgiving diſpoſition, and the wrongs your mother put upon him were of a nature not eaſily to be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Wrongs!—what wrongs, Geoffry? is the dark tale for ever to be concealed from me?— I am deſerted by my father, and not to know the cauſe!—Come, good old man! remember, you promiſed you would one day tell me, and ſince we are alone, and may not have another opportunity, come now—unveil the myſtery—how, how did my mother wrong him?

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Well then, to keep my word—Sir Hervey ever was, and I fear ever will be, a dupe to faſhion and its follies:—he gamed, he intrigued—and though in his heart devoted to Lady Sutherland, he forſook her and his home for ſcenes of riot and diſſipation.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Unfortunate infatuation!

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Lady Sutherland a long while bore this with fortitude and reſignation; but young, beautiful, and accompliſhed, ſurrounded by admirers and neglected by her huſband, ſhe at laſt liſtened to the addreſſes of an artful and deſigning villain, who convinced her of Sir Hervey's infidelity, and, by means of forged letters and other artifices, perſuaded her to elope with him.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: 'Tis too true, madam;—but her guilt was of ſhort duration:—in a few days ſhe came back to that houſe, all penitence and ſhame.—I ſhall never forget the day.—I told Sir Hervey of her return, and he in a fit of rage and madneſs bid me ſhut the door againſt her; this ſhe overheard: 'twas too much for a tender nature like hers:—ſhe fled, and ſoon after died—died of a broken heart!

sp.speaker: Juliana
sp.p: Oh, for mercy!— my poor, poor mother!

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: You were then but eight years old, and till that hour the idol of Sir Hervey:—but your likeneſs to your mother ſoon making him wiſh to avoid you, you were removed to the caſtle; where he inveſted Mrs. Dazzle with the unlimited power of a guardian over you, and which I fear ſhe has exerted like a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Yes.—Sir Hervey could not mean that I ſhould be her priſoner!—But go on: he went abroad—

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: He did — to Naples, where he has ever ſince reſided: and now, what think you, madam? do you blame the living or the dead?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: I have no right to condemn either—but in my mind the huſband who neglects an amiable wife is reſponſible for all the evils that enſue.— Died of a broken heart!—oh, that he had but pardoned her!—then he had had a wife, and I a mother to conſole me!—but now—Do I indeed reſemble her?

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: You do—you do.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Thank Heaven!—I may forgive her, though my father never can.

sp.speaker: Worry
sp.p: This way, my lad—this way.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Ha! there's Sir Hervey!—though I wiſh, you don't know how I dread to ſee him: let me be gone.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: No, 'tis only Worry, his old faithful follower; honeſt ſoul! he and your father were foſtered by the ſame nurſe; and, though long ſince in eaſy independent circumſtances, he ſtill follows Sir Hervey from motives of affection.—Suppoſe you aſk him to be a mediator for you.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Not now—another time, another time —I muſt return to my priſon:—but though I ſhed tears over the fate of my mother, don't fancy I upbraid my father.—No! I feel for both—and let him ſtill avoid, ſtill puniſh and abandon me, I know his motive: and the fond hope that he will one day prove a parent to me, will make me bear even greater ills with patience.—Oh! may that day be not far off! for 'twill be the proudeſt and the happieſt of my life.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Mind, do as I order you; when the baggage arrives let me know. (Exit Servant.) What Geoff!—give me your hand, old Geoff!—Sir Hervey is but a ſtage behind.—'Slife! I thought we ſhould never ſhake hands again.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: So did I; 'tis thirteen years (ſhaking hands and looking hard at Worry); but, heyday! how you are altered, Maſter Worry!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Yes, I'm not the ſame man I was.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: So I ſee; but how has it happened?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I don't know—I lead a different ſort of life—I think; and I'm afraid I drink a great deal.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: You drink! you that uſed to be the moſt temperate, ſober—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Ay; and I uſed to hate cards, you know; now I could play all day:—I uſed to break appointments; now I come an hour before my time; —and I that always laid in bed till noon, now conſtantly riſe with the crowing of the cock.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Why, what the deuce, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: No—I'm married.—I've got a loving jealous wife!—and whilſt Sir Hervey is continually miſerable becauſe Lady Sutherland ran away from him, here am I—I tell you what, Geoff—if Mrs. Worry were to run away from me, I'm ſure I ſhould be too much of a philoſopher to repine on the occaſion.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: What! and is Sir Hervey likewiſe altered?—or does he ſtill go on rioting in diſſipation and extravagance?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Worſe and worſe—only yeſterday he employed Mr. Alltrade to raiſe five thouſand pounds for him on his bond—offered a premium of fifty per cent. and the moment he receives the money, away it will go in galas or at the gaming table—No, I beg pardon—not at the gaming table—now a days no money ever goes there.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: What! have they left off playing?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: No—but they've left off paying;—and that's the reaſon the faro banks are knocked up— when people only play for love, friendſhip won't induce them to keep open houſe.—But Miſs Sutherland—there's Sir Hervey's greateſt plague. A meeting with her was his chief motive for leaving Italy, and now we underſtand ſhe vindicates her mother, and takes part againſt him.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: She is belied, cruelly belied!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p:
Nay; we have it from the beſt authority, —Mrs. Dazzle—the lady who brought her up, and for whom I have a meſſage—but of this be
aſſured, Geoff; Sir Hervey's caſe isn't half ſo deſperate as mine:—he's only tormented by a daughter who will try to break his heart, but I've got a jealous wife, who will actually break my head, heart, and purſe ſtrings.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, the baggage is come.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: You hear—Mrs. Worry is arrived.—Come, will you go and be introduced?

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: With all my heart—but mind now—you'll one day find that Mrs. Dazzle has traduced Miſs Sutherland, and only becauſe ſhe was a great favourite of her late huſband's. He was a diſtant relation, you know, and I did hope would have remembered her in his will—but no—he, like the reſt of her family—he—has forgotten her!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: To be ſure; who ever got any good by theſe diſtant relations? Mrs. Worry has a little thouſand; and do you know my apartments are ſo conſtantly cram'd with couſins, neices, uncles, aunts, and grandmothers, that at dinner-time I never get a chair to ſit upon—I eat flying!—And talk of the comforts of a fire-ſide, curſe me if I've been within ten yards of mine ſince the day I was married:—not that I complain of cold though—my houſe is warm enough, I promiſe you:—but come along; and ſorry am I to be convinced of Miſs Sutherland's ingratitude.—Were ſhe the girl you deſcribe, I would not only be her friend and advocate, but if Sir Hervey refuſed to protect her, I would myſelf be a father to her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Even ſo, ma'am; Miſs Juliana firſt robbed you of your huſband's friendſhip, and now of the Captain's love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Oh, the little viper!—but I know how to be amply revenged:—the great object of her life is a reconciliation with her father;—this I have already prevented, and will ſtill prevent.—But the Captain, Betty—do you think he has ſerious views?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: He ſerious! what Captain Laviſh prefer Juliana Sutherland without a ſhilling, to the widow Dazzle with a nett eſtate of five thouſand a-year!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: That's true:—I married little Jerry for his fortune, and I am certainly ſole heireſs—to be ſure I hav'nt yet ſeen the will, becauſe he died in London:—but I expect his agent Mr. Alltrade with it every moment, and then, Betty!—poor Juliana!—I hope the Captain will allow her half pay.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh you're too liberal, ma'am—but ſee! here comes Mr. Alltrade with the will.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Well! madam, as good as my word, you ſee:—this moment arrived with my friend Sir Hervey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: You are very kind, Mr. Alltrade; but there was no occaſion to be in any hurry—every body knows how little Jerry loved me.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Oh, there's no doubt that the will is completely in your favour; but you had better open it, leſt there ſhould be any ſmall bequeſt or legacies—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p:
Well, to oblige you I'll juſt caſt my eye over it— (takes the will from ALLTRADE)
Poor Jerry!—he uſed to ſay he ſhould fall a martyr to love. (Reads will): By this my laſt will, I Jeremiah Dazzle give and bequeath all the property of which I die poſſeſſed unto that moſt lovely and accompliſhed of her ſex—Spare me—ſpare a poor widow's bluſhes, Mr. Alltrade.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Nay! it's not more than you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! (curtſeying—then reads on:)—"unto that moſt lovely and accompliſhed of her ſex, Juliana Sutherland"—Juliana!—why, Mr. Alltrade! (Half crying.)

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.p: Juliana Sutherland, whom being deſerted by her father, I take a pride in adopting. But my will further is, that ſhe hold the ſaid property no longer than ſhe remains unmarried. In caſe ſhe marries, I give the ſame to my widow Deborah Dazzle. And my only motive for thus tying up my couſin Juliana, is to ſave her from entering into a ſtate to which I fell a martyr. — Why it's a forgery! he could not—dared not!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Nay—there's no doubt that it's genuine—but be compoſed—doesn't Miſs Sutherland live in this houſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: She does.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Then it dawns! it glares upon me!—Mark—if ſhe marries, the eſtate devolves to you—are not theſe Mr. Dazzle's words!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: They are: and I only wiſh I had been behind him when he wrote them!.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Well: be patient—don't deſtroy the will, becauſe that's a ſerious buſineſs (pulling up his neckcloth):—only conceal it till you get Juliana a huſband—then ſhe forfeits the legacy, and you become heireſs to a hundred thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Why that looks well—but how?—the Captain won't marry her.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: No, but I will; in the firſt place her being in this houſe will give me numberleſs opportunities; and in the next I am employed by Sir Hervey to raiſe five thouſand pounds for him on his bond—now if we can get Juliana to join in it, I ſhall have them both ſo completely in my power, that if I fail in the character of a lover, I may ſucceed in that of a creditor:—you underſtand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: I do—excellent!—and as a reward for your trouble—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I only aſk a third of the eſtate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Granted—it is a bargain.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Say you ſo?—then let's to work inſtantly—and look here comes one who, from his influence over Sir Hervey, we muſt ſecure as a confederate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Worry, my old acquaintance!—I give you joy of your marriage, and ſincerely wiſh you may never know the pangs of widowhood.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: And ſo do I with all my heart, Worry.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: And I wiſh with all my ſoul you'd both keep your wiſhes to yourſelves. (Aſide.)—But I wait upon you, madam, from Sir Hervey:—from your account of Miſs Sutherland's undutiful and indiſcreet conduct, he perſiſts in not ſeeing her, and therefore while he ſtays in the country, he begs ſhe may be more cloſely confined than ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: I'll do all I can; but ſhe is ſo artful and deſigning, that for my part I don't think ſhe'll ever be ſafe till ſhe gets a huſband to protect her.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Nor I; and I'll tell you a ſecret, Worry—I love her, and wiſh to be that huſband: and ſince, from my humble birth and inferior ſituation, I cannot aſpire to gaining Sir Hervey's conſent, will you aid and aſſiſt the marriage?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: With all my heart—the more matches the better.—When one's in a ſcrape oneſelf, nothing's ſo conſoling as to ſee all one's friends in the ſame ſituation. (Aſide.) I'll aſſiſt you—but about the bond—have you raiſed the five thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: No; and I deſpair of ſucceſs—the friend I applied to wants Miſs Sutherland to join.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: She join! why ſhe's as poor—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I know—but he ſays ſhe has rich relations—may have a handſome legacy—in ſhort, it will mend the ſecurity:—therefore let Sir Hervey know this, and he will ſee the neceſſity of commanding her to ſign inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Good day, Worry—I ſhall be always glad to ſee you: and becauſe there's a hatchment over my door, don't fancy this is abſolutely the houſe of mourning.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: No, ma'am;—I—I—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Why, what do you laugh at?—ſpeak out—you won't offend me.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Shan't I, ma'am?—then begging your pardon, you need'nt have caution'd me; for I always look on a hatchment outſide of a widow's houſe like a ſign over an inn—a certain emblem of revelry and good cheer.—And when I'm a widower—oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: So far, ſo well; he's in our intereſt—but to get this bond out of Sir Hervey's hands, we muſt at leaſt advance a few hundreds, and where to raiſe even thoſe—for my part I haven't a guinea.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Nor I now a ſhilling!— (ſighing) nor do I know where to raiſe one?

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: No; unleſs indeed Mr. Miſt the manager of our country theatre—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: What! the quondam ſilverſmith of Cheapſide!—he's an old friend of mine,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle,
sp.p: Is he?—then you may aid my ſuit.—You muſt know, ſmitten with the love of ſame, eager to acquire the reputation of wit and genius, I have written a moſt magnificent play, which of courſe I am all anxiety to ſee acted; he has already promiſed to come and read it, and if it meets with his approbation, very likely he may advance the money neceſſary to pay Sir Hervey.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: True—ſuppoſe I haſten his viſit—I'll ſeek him inſtantly; and whilſt you keep Juliana out of ſight, I'll keep the will out of ſight— (putting will in his pocket).—And with regard to the play, if you get money by it, depend on't you'll get reputation alſo; one generally follows the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: So it does—and how the caſe is alter'd?—formerly wits had no money, and now he that has no money has no wit; for whilſt a bad joke will be applauded from the head of a great able, a good one will be loſt if ſpoken by him who has nothing but wit to recommend him!—but away to the manager—let the war begin, and doubt not our victory!

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Pooh—I'll ſit there picking my teeth no longer;—ſtay for ever, there won't be a place taken; for well as Mr. Miſt might underſtand conducting a ſhop, he knows ſo little how to manage a theatre, that during the time I have been prompter, treaſurer, box-book-keeper, and deputy manager, there have been only three boxes taken—and they were by particular friends, who thought they did him an honour by coming in with orders—pſha!—I'll go—heh?—who's here?—aha? a flat at laſt!

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: This way, Sir,—there's the office—have a front row in any part of the houſe, Sir—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Sir, I want to ſpeak to Mr. Miſt—where is he? (STOPGAP holds down his head).—Why don't you anſwer me?—where can I find him?

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: He's walking on the London road—you'll find him there, all anxiety, looking out for the new Harlequin whom we expect every hour by the ſlow waggon.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Expect Harlequin by the ſlow waggon!

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Yes, Sir: and between you and me, 'tis high time he came; we play to ſhocking houſes—laſt night to Hamlet we were obliged to make a ſhew, by ſhoving the band into the pit, the orange women into the boxes, and the door-keepers into the galleries.—Indeed no wonder at it, for Mr. Miſt himſelf played Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: The old tradeſman act Hamlet!

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Even ſo—he always will act the beſt part—but here he comes, and ſpite of the bad houſes, all buſtle, life, and animation!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Damn that ſlow waggon—not here 'till ſeaſon's over—however, ſure of tol lol houſe to night—fine day—ſtrong bill—nothing againſt—what Jack! Jack Alltrade!—why what brings you to this—oh! oh!—ſly dog!—written a Farce—can't get it acted in London—and ſo come—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Not I upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Want an engagement then!—what's your line? Ben, Scrub, and Calliban; or Richard, Romeo, and the tiptops—no difference though—tragedy or comedy—play which you will, Jack—ſure to entertain audience—he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Why 'Slife—here's an alteration!—when I laſt ſaw you, you were leaving off trade with a capital fortune, and retiring into the country free from the cares and vexation of buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Hem! much you know of the matter—when I loſt care and vexation, loſt my two beſt friends.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Care and vexation your beſt friends!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
Yes: couldn't tell what to do with myſelf—all day long watching clock, or yawning at ſtreet door—could'nt bear it—hardly alive—thought of opening new ſhop—when one lucky day!—play houſe put up at auction—always had theatrical twiſt—ſo bid handſomely—knock'd down at large ſum to be ſure—but what then? been happy ever ſince—had care and vexation in abundance—but
mum—ſhan't ſtop here—London—Covent Garden—Drury Lane—they're my object!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Indeed!—then why not make them your object now?—why not engage London players?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Um! (ſnapping his fingers)—that for London players—and that for London authors—ſoon have beſt actor and fineſt writer living—heh: know who I mean?

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Harlequin!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Right—back his wooden ſword againſt their wooden heads—bring all Europe—young and old boys—little babies, and full grown babies:—and then for ſalary—only twelve ſhillings a week, and fare of ſlow waggon—whereas theſe London gentlemen, with their ten pounds a night and poſt chaiſes and four—beſides, won't do here?—don't I come from London?—don't I act Hamlet, and to what?—not enough to pay the lighting?—but can't ſtay—muſt go look after the tricks—muſt get all ſmooth 'gainſt great man's arrival.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Nay: I've an invitation for you—Mrs. Dazzle is extremely anxious about her play, and requeſts you'd wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: I wait!—who's manager?—beſides d—d ſtuff I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: That I can't ſay—but when I tell you, ſhe is a lady I have the greateſt regard for—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Enough—come this evening—be there before doors open—till when, in the words of Hamlet, Remember me!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Hamlet!—in the words of the Ghoſt, you mean.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
Yes: but when I act Hamlet, play the Ghoſt too—always take every good ſpeech in the
play and whip into my part—I'm manager—he! he! he!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Well, adieu—and after the reading, I'll look in at the theatre.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Do—ſhan't coſt you a farthing—put you in at ſtage door, and ſit in my box—Strong bill tonight—Beggar's Opera in two acts—Filch by a gentleman of the law, being his firſt and laſt appearance on any ſtage—after which, a grand ſpectacle of my own writing, called Gulliver the Great.—In the firſt act, all the characters will be killed—in the ſecond, introduced their executors, adminiſtrators, and aſſigns—but come and judge.—I ſay though, when new pantomime comes out, trouble you not to walk about the town, Jack.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Why!—who'll pay to look at my clown, when they can ſee you for nothing—he! he! he!—come along, Stop.

div.trailer: THE END OF THE FIRST ACT.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE—Outſide of the Caſtle.
div.stage: Enter Sir HERVEY SUTHERLAND, WORRY, and GEOFFRY.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! how mortifying! how perplexing!—and yet, without the money, inevitable ruin follows. Are you ſure that was Mr. Alltrade's meſſage?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; he cannot raiſe the five thouſand pounds unleſs Miſs Juliana joins in the bond.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Well, be it ſo.—Enter the caſtle inſtantly, and tell her 'tis by my command; the firſt and laſt requeſt her father ever will make to her—begone— [WORRY exit].—And now, old man, obey my orders—let there be maſks and dancing—I cannot encounter ſolitude—that leads to thought, and thought engenders madneſs; and I muſt plunge 'midſt any ſpecies of ſociety to ſave me from myſelf: therefore, let the doors of Sutherland-houſe once more be opened, and let revelry and good cheer welcome my return.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: I ſhall obey, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Give general invitation to my friends.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Your friends!—Oh, I'm glad of that, Sir—then I hope I know one who will be of the party.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Indeed! who, Geoffry?

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: With ſubmiſſion, Miſs Juliana, Sir— don't be angry—but if the title of friend admits any one into your houſe, in my mind none ôught to be more welcome than your own daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: How!—have a care, Sir.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Nay, you are deceived, cruelly deceived; ſhe has no hope, no wiſh beyond you: only this very morning, with tears in her eyes, ſhe exclaimed, The day that reconciles me to my father will be the proudeſt and the happieſt of my life!—Theſe were her words—and now, to ſee her impriſoned!—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey
sp.p: Did ſhe—did ſhe ſay this, Geoffry?

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: She did, Sir—and at the ſame time ſhe put on ſuch a ſweet faſcinating look—exactly ſuch a one as her late mother—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Who, Sir?

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Such a one as poor Lady Sutherland, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Diſtraction!—you've raiſed the latent fury here; and I would ſooner preſs a viper to my breaſt than the image of a woman who had ſo wronged me.—I'll hear no more—beſides, this is all artifice—I've been informed how well ſhe loves her father; and for the impriſonment you talk of, I ſanction and approve it.—Better be even cloiſtered thus, than only come into the world to vindicate and ſhare a falſe, falſe mother's crimes.

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: What! can Mrs. Dazzle be baſe enough—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p:
Peace, old man—on pain of your diſmiſſal utter not a word againſt that beſt of women and of friends.—Attend me home, and
inſtantly make preparation for ſplendid hoſpitality.—

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Look, Sir!—only look!—there's poor Miſs Juliana ſitting at her priſon window!—ſee, how innocent and how melancholy ſhe appears!— Suppoſe now you were juſt to ſtay and—and— ſpeak to her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I ſpeak!—away!—lead not my mind to thoughts that madden whilſt they charm me—No—in the huſband's wrongs I'll bury all the fond, fond feelings of the father.—

sp.speaker: Geoffry.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, only turn and take one look at her—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I dare not—I dare not—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Oh, what a fate is mine!—a father, whom I haven't ſeen from infancy, and now ſo near me—and I'm denied the ſight of him—nay more, am told that, by his orders, this place is ſtill to be my priſon.—Oh, my mother! I feel my heart, like yours, can't long ſupport it.— (Weeps.)—I ſhall ſoon follow thee!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: So, there ſhe is—what a frightful, undutiful countenance!—Oh, ſhe'll ſee us all ſtarve before—Madam!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: As I live, the man that Geoffry ſpoke of—what can he want?— (Advances towards him.) —May I aſk—I hope Sir Hervey's well?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: No, he's very ill, I'm very much obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Ill!—heavens!—what's his complaint?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: An ungrateful daughter!—Your pardon, ma'am—perhaps I'm ſomewhat blunt—but I have lived with Sir Hervey theſe twenty years: if he has faults to others, he has none to me; and though the world deſerts him, it is my duty to ſtand or fall with him.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Well, I applaud your zeal; but why, why charge me with ingratitude?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Becauſe you are his enemy; becauſe you take the part of her who baſely wrong'd him.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Hold, cenſure me as much as you pleaſe; but breathe not a ſyllable againſt my mother.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: There! you avow it; you juſtify—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: No—but I feel for her; I lament her fate: that conſolation Sir Hervey cannot deny me. —And let him know me before he condemns me; for how can that child be called ungrateful who never had an opportunity of evincing either her duty or affection?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: I never wronged him; and even in my infancy he ſhut his doors againſt me.—I am his child; and by denying his protection, he has expoſed me to the ſelf-ſame ſnares my mother fell a martyr to.—I've not diſgraced—I've ever loved him: and let him give me but the trial—oh! let him take me to his heart; and if the careſſes of an affectionate daughter do not atone for the errors of a miſguided mother, then let him caſt me from him; but till then let him not accuſe me of ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: What! and you'd—how handſome ſhe looks!—you'd be loving and dutiful?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Oh yes—I'd watch, I'd nurſe him— weep as he wept, and bleſs each ſmile that cheered him: and when time had mellowed his grief into a ſweet remembrance of my mother's loſs, then I'd retrieve her honour in the grave:—in my unvaried truth, all, all ſhould be forgotten. I would revive the friendſhip that he bore her, and ſhe ſhould live again in Juliana.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul!—now only think of my not marrying ſuch a woman!—and if he wanted money, and you had it to lend him—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: If I had millions, I would devote them all to him.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Old Geoff's right.—May I never go to Heaven if ſhe isn't an angel!—and if the widow isn't ſomething elſe, may I go ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Ay, Mrs. Dazzle; ſhe is my perſecutor: from the hour I accidentally interfered with her in Captain Laviſh's affection, ſhe—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Captain Laviſh!—what, your father's antagoniſt—the man who two years ago fought him in Switzerland?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Alas! the ſame.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: And did you return his affection?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: What could I do?—he riſked his own life to ſave mine—'tis but a ſhort and ſimple tale— One day, when I had liberty to ride within the precincts of the caſtle, my horſe ran away with me, and he in ſtopping it broke his arm: I could do no leſs than confeſs the obligation; and ſince his recovery, often viſiting Mrs. Dazzle, our intimacy encreaſed, and gratitude grew into love.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: And all the time did you know of the duel?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: No; till yeſterday I never heard of it; and then I inſtantly informed him, that though Sir Hervey neglected his duty to me, I could never forget mine to him, and nothing ſhould induce me to receive that man as a lover, who deſigned to be the murderer of my father. (WORRY croſſes her as if going)—Why, what's the matter?—where are you going?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: To Sir Hervey; to bid him remove you from the protection of a hypocrite, and place you under his own.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Oh, will you—will you be ſo generous? Indeed in this caſtle I am not ſafe a moment.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: No—nor any body elſe; for the roof will tumble in to a certainty; but I'll go directly: and if I fail, and the war continues—let the enemy look to it—I've ſerved many a hard campaign, and though not lately in the battles abroad, thanks to Mrs. Worry I've ſeen pretty warm ſervice at home; and ſooner than you ſhould remain under the rod of a tyrant, I'd ſtorm the caſtle, and revive the age of chivalry:—yes—I would—I "Will Worry," the married man!—So retire, and wait my coming, madam—I'll not be long.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: I'm ſure you will not: and pray remind my father, that I have ſuffered in my turn; that we are partners in calamity, and by meeting we might divide and diſſipate each other's woes.—Tell him—but you know my thoughts, and to your conduct I commit a cauſe on which my hope, my happineſs, my life depends!

div.head: SCENE—Another Apartment in the Caſtle, Mrs. DAZZLE and MIST diſcovered ſitting at a Table— MIST with a Manuſcript in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Now then, Mr. MIST—now begin the play: but remember, I haven't quite finiſhed it.

sp.speaker: Miſt
sp.p: Mary Queen of Scots, a grand beroic drama; with new ſcenes, new dreſſes, new decorations, new —hem: that's my affair—I'm manager—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Oh, certainly, Sir—

sp.speaker: Miſt
sp.p: Scene the firſt—a room in a Caſtle—the Duke of Norfolk diſcovered with a key in his band. The Duke—Now, by my holy dame, with this ſame key, Jockey of Norfolk, thou'lt unlock the gate of Scottiſh Mary's priſon!—He unlocks ihe gate and leads forth Mary.—Beſhrew me, but your ſafe, and ſo good morrow, good Queen Elizabeth!— (MIST lays down the play, and riſes:) Won't do—won't bring ſixpence—refuſe it—I refuſe it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: How! why I flattered myſelf I had caught the true Shakſperian fire.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: And ſuppoſe you had—what then?—played Hamlet laſt night under ten pounds; and I ſay that's a bad play that brings a bad houſe.—Harlequin and Abraham Newland—they're the only pulling writers, except indeed the Germans; and there!—there I'm beforehand with the Londoners— mum—mine's a German Harlequin—he!—he!— However, try another page—if that's not better, don't you finiſh play—audience will finiſh it for you.

Enter Queen Elizabeth and Burleigh.—The Queen—Go to—we'll nip'em i'the bud.—Why, how now, rebels?—for this treacherous queen, convey her to the tower—and there, good Burleigh—You take the hint—Away! —Burleigh carries off Mary and — (here MIST is interrupted by loud rattling at ſtage door)—You hear— applauſe interrupts us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Who can it be?—dear! was there ever any thing ſo unlucky?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Not at all; for this relief much thanks— (taking up his hat and cane).—Decided, in my opinion—firſt night diſapprobation—ſecond, under expences—third, nobody but the author.—Yours, devotedly yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Nay, I inſiſt you don't ſtir (noiſe at door again).—You hear!—do only be kind enough to ſtep into the next room, and I'll get rid of this intruſive perſon in a moment: come now, indulge an anxious author; and conſider though it don't read, it may act well.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: That's true; nothing reads worſe than pantomime; but in repreſentation!—Oh gods! and goddeſſes!—give me the manuſcript—I'll indulge you (takes the play)—one—two—only four acts!— never mind—if play's bad, leſs of bad thing the better—if good, I and my copyiſt ſoon cobble up fifth act for you—but I'm gone— (Going, returns) Mum! ever ſee Gulliver the Great?—that was our writing—to be ſure audience damn'd it the firſt night, but what then?—Theatre's mine!—ſo gave 'em a doſe of it; acted it fifty nights running—revenged myſelf there—he! he! he!—and in like manner always will maintain dignity!—always, as long as I'm P. M., Peter Miſt—and M. P. manager of a play houſe!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Now then, for this tormentor— (opens door, and enter JULIANA)—You Miſs!—how dare you—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Oh, madam!—I'm ſo terrified!—even now, Mr. Alltrade, a total ſtranger, propoſed marriage to me; and told me that, aided by his own merit and your intereſt, he didn't doubt of ſucceſs, —Nay, on my refuſing him, he abſolutely threatened to uſe force.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: And on this account you fled from him?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: I did, madam: and I entreat you to protect and ſave me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Baſe, worthleſs girl!—then know Mr. Alltrade ſpoke truth; he is the man I have ſelected for your huſband.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Heavens! and can you mean—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: I mean you ſhould be his wife! and till you conſent, your chamber ſhall be your priſon—

sp.speaker: Juliana
sp.p: Oh, for mercy! —Look at me—I am friendleſs, fatherleſs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: And who have you to thank for it?—Yes: 'tis as I ſaid—Captain Laviſh has taught you to deſpiſe marriage, and copy the example of her who made you fatherleſs.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: What! do you allude to—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: I do—and beware, Miſs—dare not to imitate ſuch falſe, abandoned conduct.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Abandoned!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Ay: would you juſtify it?—have you the audacity to vindicate deeds the moſt licentious!—actions—

sp.speaker: Juliana
sp.p:
Were you the being that I moſt reſpect—were you my father!—I'd tell you it is falſe!—Licentious!—oh, had my illfated mother
poſſeſſed one atom that reſembled you, I'd tear her image from my heart, or die!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Take care, or—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Oh, ſhame! ſhame!—is this the protection I might expect from one of my own ſex?— Men would betray us; let us not betray each other! and while ſhe whom you cenſure might meet with pity and forgiveneſs, what can the female ſeducer expect?—the ſcorn of one ſex, the abhorrence of the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Begone I—retire to your chamber—nay, no reply;—I will be obeyed—
sp.stage: (walks up the ſtage in a rage).

sp.speaker: Juliana
sp.p: Oh! have you ſeen my father?—will he, will he take pity on me?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Alas, madam!—I can do nothing for you.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: What! he perſiſts!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Moſt obſtinately: he ſays your offer of advancing money is no more than your duty, and what a parent has a lawful claim to.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Then may he feel—but he's deceived, and I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.p: Not gone yet!—Do as I command: to your chamber I inſiſt — (takes JULIANA by the arm and leads her to ſtage door—JULIANA exit.)—And you, Worry, as you've kindly undertaken to aſſiſt Mr. Alltrade, go to him inſtantly; tell him Miſs Sutherland has ſo groſsly inſulted me, that I've no longer any conſcientious ſcruples, and if he chooſes to ſecure the marriage by carrying her off—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Carrying her off!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Ay: force will be the ſhorteſt mode: ſo bid him come in a poſt-chaiſe to the weſtern gate, whilſt I go and make ſure of my priſoner.—Away—loſe not a moment, and tell him I'll anſwer for the ſucceſs of the enterprize.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I go to Mr. Alltrade!—I aid—bleſs my ſoul!—No wonder ſhe's a widow—If ſhe married every morning, her huſband would die before night: —but I will aid in carrying her off—I'll go directly and get aſſiſtance—I'll entreat the firſt man I meet to join with me:—and let Sir Hervey condemn, or, what's more tremendous, let Mrs. Worry ſcold me, I know I'm doing my duty!—So in ſpite of wives, widows, and devils, I'll ſecure her eſcape, and ſtill try to reſtore her to her father.

div.stage: Re-enter MIST (with the Play in his hand).

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Oh, it won't do—'twill be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Now pray take pity—pray give your aſſiſtance, Sir:—there's the ſweeteſt young lady juſt lock'd into that room, and if you would but help to releaſe her—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: How! what! young lady lock'd up! and I help to releaſe her!—pooh—nonſenſe!—what's her caſe!—And me—why apply to me?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Becauſe I'm ſure you will befriend us— and if you did but know how well ſhe had conducted herſelf!—how charmingly ſhe had acted her part—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: What! acted her part!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Ay! no woman ever acted better:— ſuch ſenſe! ſuch feeling, Sir!—and now, when ſhe is ſo ready to engage herſelf—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
Ready to engage!—oh, ho—comprehend now—lock'd up to keep her from the ſtage, and
apply to me 'cauſe I'm Manager—he! he!—Hark ye; how's her voice?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Delightful.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: And her action?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Graceful.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: And her figure?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Beautiful.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Damme ſhe'll do my buſineſs till Harlequin comes! Say no more—my houſe is open— I'll give her an appearance.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: What!—you'll get her out!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: To be ſure I will—in what part ſhe likes beſt —tragedy, comedy, opera, farce, pantomime!— And you!—want a clown—you ſhall play clown— alſo if you're married! don't reply—ſee it by your chin—give you and your wife freedom—perpetual free admiſſion.—But now for it—now to plan plot —Hem!—Here is the author.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.stage: (locking doors and putting the key in her pocket).
sp.p: So now Juliana's ſafe, and I get my huſband's eſtate.—Oh, Worry, have you ſeen Mr. Alltrade?

sp.speaker: Worry
sp.p: Hey! yes—I've ſeen Mr. Alltrade, and he'll be here with the chaiſe directly.

sp.speaker: Miſt
sp.p: "Burleigh carries off Mary."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: What! no further, Mr. Miſt?— I ſuppoſe you're thinking of the effect, Mr. Manager?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Mr. Manager!—Oh! I underſtand now—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
Yes; but can't tell without rehearſal— cannot judge unleſs I ſaw it on the boards—Let me ſee—there's the priſon gate— (pointing to folding
doors): —you are Jockey Norfolk—no I'm Jockey—I'll tell you what—ſuppoſe we give it a trial!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: A trial! what a rehearſal now in this room?—Delightful!—I ſhould like it of all things.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: So ſhould I—then liſten—I'll play Norfolk—you Queen Elizabeth—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: He, Burleigh—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Who the devil's Burleigh.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: And for Mary—dear! dear! where ſhall we get a Mary?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Tell you—all in way of rehearſal—young lady you juſt lock'd in—ſhe's in ſame ſituation you know.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: So ſhe is—here, Worry!—here's an excellent opportunity to take her to Mr. Alltrade. (Aſide to WORRY, who nods to her ſignificantly.)—I declare I ca'nt help laughing.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: No more can I:—Oh damme, I ſee it will produce an effect now?—give me the key (Mrs. DAZZLE gives it him).—All to our ſeparate places, and let rehearſal begin.—Enter Duke of Norfolk. (Puts himſelf in a mock tragic attitude, and ſpeaks bombaſtically.) Now! by my holy dame, with this ſame key, Jockey of Norfolk, thou'lt unlock the gate of Scottiſh Mary's priſon. (Unlocks folding doors, and leads out JULIANA).—Beſhrew me, but you're ſafe, and ſo good morrow, good Queen Elizabeth!

p.q: Go to—we'll nip 'em in the bud.—Why, how now, rebels?—For this treacherous Queen—(ſeizing JULIANA, and delivering her to WORRY; who puts himſelf in a tragic attitude)—convey her to the tower!—and there, good Burleigh —You take the hint!—Away!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Ay:—You take the hint!—Away!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Oh yes:—I take the hint—Away!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Bravo!—will it meet with diſapprobation now?—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: No—it muſt be a very illnatured audience indeed, that don't applaud ſo ingenious an exit.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Ay: there's authorſhip for you!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Egad, and there's management for you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Remember, Sir, but for me theſe characters wouldn't have been brought on the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: No; and but for you they wouldn't have been got off the ſtage; but now to get Norfolk off—Muſt follow new actreſs.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Stop! I'll tell you; Elizabeth firſt turns her back upon him—then Norfolk makes a long harangue—then—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Pſha! hang long harangues,—touch and go,—that's the plan for effect; I'll ſhew you how to do Norfolk's exit!—firſt turn your back on me P. S.— (Mrs. DAZZLE turns her back on him.)—So, then I ſtrut off O. P.—Gently—don't turn round till I'm gone: then work yourſelf into a furious paſſion.—Mary, I fly!—I follow thee! and ſo, good morrow, good Queen Elizabeth!—Hem,—there's another good exit!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Oh, the old fool! how I ſhall wheedle him!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Is he gone! now then to work myſelf into a furious paſſion— (turns round.)—thou wretch! thou traitor!—How! Sir Hervey!—Mr.—Heavens! have you ſeen nothing of Miſs Sutherland?—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: No; and Sir Hervey has brought the bond on purpoſe for me to preſent to her, and now, to our aſtoniſhment, we find ſhe and Worry have juſt gone out of the caſtle together:—what can it mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Mean! (burſts into tears)—that I am wheedl'd myſelf.—Oh that brute of a manager!—Sir Hervey, 'tis too plain—ſhe has elop'd.—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Elop'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: No doubt ſhe has fled to Captain Laviſh; and theſe two impoſtors are his agents.—oh, I ſee it all! ſhe has long intended it; and to avoid ſigning the bond, ſhe has haſtened her departure.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Elope with Laviſh, why this outdoes her mother:—but can I ſtand idly by?—no—I'll diſappoint my enemy of this unmanly triumph, and ſave her; ſpite of herſelf I'll ſave her—Mr. Alltrade, wait upon him inſtantly, and bid him reſtore my daughter on pain of a ſecond and more deſperate meeting.—Come, madam, we'll ſee him on his way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: By all means, Sir Hervey: I only hope you don't blame me for my pupil's indiſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: No: had ſhe copied your bright and excellent example, this ne'er had happened—but though her errors even exceed her mother's, and a reconciliation is more than ever diſtant, yet ſhe is ſtill my child!—and in a moment dangerous as the preſent, for my own ſake I'll prove a friend and father.

div.trailer: THE END OF THE SECOND ACT.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE—An Apartment in LAVISH's Houſe—Receſs with ſmall Folding Doors, which are thrown open, and diſcover a Marble Pedeſtal ſurrounded by Doves and Cupids—a Table with Wine and Refreſhments upon it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ſo you've no ſooner finiſhed that whimſical out-of-the-way job (pointing to the receſs)—than he ſends for you about another.

sp.speaker: Workman.
sp.p: Ay, your maſter is an excellent cuſtomer,—always up to his chin in brick and mortar; and then for price—'gad! he never haggles about price.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, and the beſt of the joke is, he calls himſelf an economiſt, and comes down here on a ſaving ſcheme.

sp.speaker: Workman.
sp.p: A ſaving ſcheme!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Ay! finding himſelf a little out of elbows in London, and the preſent ſtate of the Continent not allowing him to travel, he came here to
live cheap, and retrench.—And there! (pointing to receſs again)—there's one ſpecimen of his economy.—On the journey he bought a ſtatue of Venus.

sp.speaker: Workman.
sp.p: I know; and a great bargain it was: it only coſt him five pounds.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: True; but not chooſing to have his beauties gazed at, he employed you to build that ſtrange ſort of receſs to put it in, which has coſt him at leaſt five times the ſum.—This is always the way; if he bought a cheap boat, he'd cut a canal for it; and if a pulpit, he'd build a church for it:—in fact, he is a falſe economiſt—a ſelf-deceiver; and here he comes to elucidate my deſcription.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Oh! if I go on in this cloſe ſaving way only ſix months longer, I ſhall be able to return to town and daſh like the beſt of them:—never was ſuch a hand at buying bargains.—Frank, come here you rogue:—juſt now, at Squire Brozier's ſale, what do you think I gave for a curricle? — only forty pounds! — there, there's economy for you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Economy!—begging your pardon, Sir,—I ſee no economy in buying what you don't want.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: How?—would you let a bargain flip through your fingers, you extravagant raſcal?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No—but you've no horſes, Sir; and a curricle's uſeleſs—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: That's what I ſaid; ſays I, a curricle is uſeleſs without horſes,—ſo I bought a pair directly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Bought a pair?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Ay, gave a hundred and twenty pounds for them—to be ſure it's money; but one's own carriage ſaves poſting and drivers: in ſhort, the worſt come to the worſt, 'tis but a hundred and fifty pounds, and I'll ſave it a thouſand ways.—Who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Workman.
sp.p: I have finiſh'd that job, all but fixing up the ſtatue, Sir; and now I come about the billiard-room:—but, to ſpeak honeſtly, it is not worth repairing.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: So I thought; I thought it wasn't worth repairing.

sp.speaker: Workman.
sp.p: No, Sir; and a new room will not coſt above three hundred pounds:—but then to be ſure it will be elegant and laſting.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: So it will, and the firſt expence is the leaſt; ſo up with the new room.— (Workman exit.)—And now to finiſh my vindication to Juliana— (Sits at the table and writes):— Your late mother was not only my relation, but my friend and benefactreſs; and on Sir Hervey's one day reprobating her conduct with unuſual aſperity, gratitude prompted me to defend it perhaps more warmly than I ought, and a duel was the reſult.— (Knocking at the door.)—See who's there.— (FRANK exit.)—But what ſignifies writing? while ſhe's immured in her preſent den, I haven't a chance of ſucceſs.—Mrs. Dazzle formerly ſeduced me into ſome gallantries, and a diſappointed widow is the devil.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Sir, I beg pardon for laughing; but who do you think is at the door?—no leſs a gentleman
than the one you caned at Newmarket about four years ago.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Caned!—Oh! I recollect—I detected him in an act of forgery.—But what does the fellow want?—I don't know his name, nor have I once ſeen him ſince.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No; and though he now aſks for Captain Laviſh, he little thinks you are the gentleman he is under ſuch obligations to.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Shew him up (FRANK exit);—introduce the Newmarket gentleman to his two old antagoniſts the Captain and his cane.—And, in the mean time—
sp.stage: (Sits at table, and takes up pen again).

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This way, Sir—there, that's my maſter
sp.stage: (pointing to LAVISH, whoſe back is turned towards ALLTRADE).

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Oh, that's Captain Laviſh, is it?—Sir, I wait upon you—

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: Yes, the widow is ſo jealous and ſo violent.— (Turns round.)—How d'ye do, my fine fellow?—how d'ye do?—My Newmarket hero ſure enough.—

sp.speaker: Alltrade
sp.p: Amazement! why it's the very man who—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: What's the matter?—you ſeem cold—ſhall I warm you?

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Warm me!—no—I—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Some wine—give the gentleman ſome wine.—This is the houſe of frugality, and therefore I can't offer you a great variety; but as far as Burgundy, Madeira, and Champagne—muſt drink them, if I ſave it a thouſand ways.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Sir, you'll exeuſe me.—Why ſurely I've miſtaken my man—he would never be ſo civil: at all events he don't recollect me; ſo I'll pluck up courage.— (Aſide.)—Sir, I wait upon you from Sir Hervey Sutherland: he arrived here today, and knowing of your love for his daughter—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Came down to increaſe her confinement, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: No trifling, Sir; he is convinced you are concerned in her elopement—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Elopement!—how!—what!—Juliana eloped?

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: You know ſhe has, Sir; and Sir Hervey inſiſts—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Eloped!—Juliana free!—out of the widow's and her father's cuſtody!—Which way did ſhe go?—what road did ſhe take?—ſpeak, ſpeak this inſtant.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I ſpeak!—if I knew, of courſe you would be the laſt man I ſhould give information to.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Certainly.—Sir Hervey is my friend, and if his daughter isn't at preſent in your power, I ſhall unite with him in oppoſing your purſuit of her.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: You will!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, were you ever at Newmarket?

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Newmarket, Sir!—I—I—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Ay, Newmarket, Sir, Newmarket.—Frank, give me my cane.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Stay, Sir—what do you want with your cane?

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: Only to help your memory.—Look!— (ſhaking it)—were you ever at Newmarket?

sp.speaker: Alltrade
sp.p: Yes, I was, Sir.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: And you'll oppoſe me in purſuing—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: No, believe me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: And if you knew which road ſhe took—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I'd tell you, upon my honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Then retire—begone this inſtant.—And d'ye hear, if you're not ſatisfied with this treatment, call again, and I'll give you a warmer reception— (ſhaking his cane, ALLTRADE exit).—And now for Juliana—now for the idol of my ſoul!—Frank, get the curricle: no, I ſhall only hurry and lame my own horſes—get a chaiſe and four.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Chaiſe and four!—is this the way to retrench?—and conſider, Sir, Miſs Sutherland has no money; and you always ſaid you'd never marry any woman who had leſs than ten thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: I did: but that's an aukward ſum: a woman with ten thouſand pounds expects houſes, horſes, carriages—in ſhort, to ſpend double her own income, and her huſband's too. But a woman without a farthing; ſhe manages the houſe, mends the linen, nurſes the children, ſcolds the ſervants—Oh! that's the real rich wife—and the poor Juliana will be the beſt bargain I ever made.—So go, do as I tell you: and obſerve, I'll marry her if I ſacrifice my whole fortune in the purſuit.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sacrifice your whole fortune, Sir!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Ay, I will, if I ſave it a thouſand ways.

div.head: SCENE—Outſide of LAVISH's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. DAZZLE—her hat and cloak on.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: So, now to enter this perfidious Captain's houſe.—Not only love and jealouſy urge me to ſeparate him and Juliana; but as I know he don't mean to marry her, it is my buſineſs to get her once more into Alltrade's power:—yes, Miſs Juliana; let me recover my huſband's hundred thouſand pounds, and I'll warrant I'll recover my Captain. He, like the reſt of the world, won't viſit virtue in a cottage, but place me in a magnificent houſe,—ay, there's the ſecret:—now-a-days people viſit the building, not the owner of it; and on the ſize of the rooms, and the number of the entertainments, we may not only calculate our friends and admirers, but alſo the good and bad opinion of the whole faſhionable world!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Look out; we are purſued:—I'm ſure they were Mrs. Dazzle's ſervants.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: They were! but we've outrun them.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Yes: but if they come up with us, I ſhall be forced back and endure encreaſed perſecution:—Oh! I wiſh we were ſafe at this Mr. MIST'S houſe.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: So do I:—though you ſee what a ſtrange gentleman he is!—he left us to examine the firſt ſlow waggon we met; but don't deſpond, madam:—I won't leave you—no, I'll die firſt.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Kind—generous! but I cannot bear to involve you: remember you have a wife, and—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Remember!—I ſhall never forget it!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Nay: but a huſband is of ſo much conſequence to his family—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Bleſs you, I'm of no conſequence; nobody ever wants me:—if any body leaves a card, it's for Mrs. Worry:—if any body ſends an invitation, it's for Mrs. Worry:—if an invitation is ſent in return, it's ſtill Mrs. Worry: nobody calls or aſks after the huſband, except indeed the tradeſpeople!—they are kind enough now and then to notice me: but like other great married men, I'm obliged to be out when they call: ſo, curſe me if I've even the pleaſure of being at home to a dun! but we waſte time, let us proceed to Mr. Miſt's houſe.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Ay: for Heaven's ſake diſpatch—

sp.speaker: Alltrade
sp.p: You take that ſide of the road, I'll take this:—ſhe cannot eſcape then.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: There, 'tis Mr. Alltrade's voice!— and both ſides of the road are guarded by enemies.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Yes: it's all over—we're between two fires.—Which way ſhall we go?— (Pointing to LAVISH's door:) that door ſtands moſt invitingly open, ſuppoſe we enter it.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Do—inſtantly: why, what's the matter? you were quite valiant juſt now!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I was: but I fancy my courage is more like a new acquaintance than an old friend,—profeſſes a great deal at firſt, but generally ſneaks off in the hour of danger: however, lead on—and let us hope to receive from ſtrangers that protection which friends have denied us.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: So—there ſhe goes into Captain LAVISH'S houſe: bravo, Miſs JULIANA!—and there ſhe may ſtay for me: I'll to Sir Hervey inſtantly, and let him come himſelf and fight it out: for all the legacies regiſtered in Doctors Commons ſhould not induce me to re-enter thoſe doors and receive another warm reception!

div.head: SCENE—Inſide LAVISH'S houſe, receſs, &c. as in firſt Scene of this Act.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Now you've ſearched every part of the houſe; now are you ſatisfied Miſs Sutherland is not concealed in it?—'Sdeath! to detain me at ſuch a moment—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: No:—ſhe's not in the houſe I grant you; but the chaiſe! the chaiſe and four!—pray, moſt economical Captain, do you uſually travel with four horſes?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Always:—it's by far the cheapeſt plan: it ſhortens the journey, ſaves ſtopping at inns; in ſhort, the additional ſhilling is no object, and if I had but ten pounds a-year, I'd always travel with four horſes:—and now, my dear widow, allow me to ſee you home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Take care, Sir:—diſappointed love knows no bounds; and recollect it is in my power to expoſe you to my rival:—I have your letters in my poſſeſſion,—letters in which you laugh and rail at marriage:—letters—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Nay, be patient.—There now! this it is to be dragooned into an attachment,—ſhe has me, by all that's frugal!— (Aſide.)—Come then, ſit down, and let us drink to the revival of our friendſhip!—See: here's famous Madeira!—ay: you may ſtare: but this too is on the cheapeſt plan I promiſe you, for while it takes two bottles of port to make me drunk, one of Madeira does it completely.— So here's to the rival— (tapping hard at ſtage door P. S.)—Why, what's that? ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Mercy!—ſomebody's coming!— for heaven's ſake don't let me be ſeen—I'll ſtep into this room—
sp.stage: (Goes to ſtage door O. P. and tapping beard there).

sp.speaker: Worry
sp.p: Madam, where are you, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Why, what is all this?—it is done on purpoſe to expoſe me!—Oh, Mr. Laviſh! if you have either feeling or gallantry, think of my ſituation: a widow only a fortnight, and to be detected alone in a Captain's houſe!—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Well! ſtep into that receſs—quick, quick— (Mrs. DAZZLE in her hurry drops her cloak, then enters receſs, and LAVISH faſtens the door upon her). —So—there I have you faſt; and now—

sp.speaker: Juliana
sp.p: Mr. Worry, why don't you anſwer? me, my dear Mr. Worry.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Damme, I'll Worry you—I'll anſwer you (opens door and enter JULIANA): Heaven's! Miſs Sutherland!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Mr. Laviſh! I beg pardon, Sir:— when I took refuge in this houſe, I little thought to meet you.—Good day, Sir.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: What! now—the very moment that I've found you?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: What can I do, Mr. Laviſh!—I own I owe you obligations—nay, more—I confeſs I could have loved you:—but I have told you my determination—you are my father's enemy—therefore we cannot be friends:—farewel, Sir!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Mighty well, madam, mighty well!— but this isn't your real motive—you love another: you love this Mr. Worry!—anſwer me candidly, ma'am!—did he not run away with you?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: He did!—but—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: He did!—then may I run into every ſpecies of extravagance, if when I catch him, I don't give him the Newmarket flouriſh (ſhaking his cane).—Where is he?—where is this Mr. Worry?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Here at your ſervice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: This my rival!—this antient, wizen, dowager-like—Don't be unmanly, Laviſh!—never ſtrike an old woman I intreat you (throwing away his cane).—Beſides now I look at him, it is! 'tis Sir Hervey's—you dear, amiable, agreeable:—one Mrs. WORRY is ſufficient for you, or the devil's in't.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Very likely, Sir: but if you have no rival in an old woman, as you pleaſe to call me, I fancy Miſs Sutherland has! when I liſtened at the door, I'll ſwear I heard the widow's voice.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: The widow!—no, Juliana—I can prove myſelf as great an economiſt in love as in money.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Are you ſure you can, Sir?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Sure!—if ſince the hour I firſt beheld her, I haven't treaſured every thought, hoarded every look!—ſtored—

sp.speaker: Worry
sp.stage: (pointing to Mrs. DAZZLE's cloak on the ground).
sp.p: Pray, SIR, who does that cloak belong to?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: That cloak!—Oh that cloak is one of my bargains.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Is it? then you buy very dear bargains, I fancy.—Look, madam,— (taking up clock) isn't it Mrs. Dazzle's?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: It is: and ſince this confirms what I have long ſuſpected, I have now an additional motive for avoiding you.—Mr. Laviſh, we never meet again.—Come

sp.speaker: Worry
sp.p: I ſay, if you don't hoard your money better than your love, never think of matrimony—you'll find it too expenſive a bargain for you, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey Sutherland
sp.p: Where is he? —where is Captain Laviſh?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Sir Hervey! 'Slife! what brings him here?

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: My father! oh Heavens! and to find me under the roof of his enemy—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: And me alſo!—Mrs. Worry herſelf couldn't terrify me more.—Come along, madam, and let's leave the Captain to ſtand the brunt.—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Ay: loſe not a moment.—And oh, Mr. Laviſh! as this is the laſt time we ſhall ever meet, remember the parting words of her you once regarded—Pacify my father, do not incence him—be his friend, and 'ſpite of your falſhood and unkindneſs, you may ſtill be mine.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: And mine—ha! ha! there's another bad bargain for him!

div.stage: (JULIANA exit—WORRY is following, when LAVISH lays bold of him and prevents his going).

sp.speaker: Holloa!
sp.p: what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: So, Mr. Laviſh; 'tis ſtill doomed that we're to meet as enemies—where is Miſs Sutherland, Sir?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Sir Hervey, on the honour of a gentleman, I know nothing of your daughter's elopement; for any further information I refer you to Mr. Worry (puſhing WORRY forwards). I ſay, who has the beſt of the bargain now?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! I've a great mind— (advancing towards WORRY, and ſtopping)—but he is only agent;—to you as principal, I look for reparation and redreſs.—Hear me, Sir—Mrs. Dazzle, a lady of the ſtricteſt truth and honour—ſhe firſt informed me of your infamous deſigns, and now—not half an hour ago, a friend, on whoſe word I can equally rely, ſaw Miſs Sutherland enter this very houſe: therefore there is no alternative but this—inſtantly reſtore her, or—you gueſs the reſult.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: I do—but I'll waſte no more powder, Sir Hervey.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No: dying is certainly a cheap mode of living, and to a man in deſperate circumſtances, a duel may be a good ſaving ſcheme: but having hoarded enough to make life comfortable, why I'm a curſt fool if I don't ſave it a thouſand ways.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Poor, paltry prevarication!—Remember, Mr. Laviſh, we were once friends—I treated you as a ſon—you eſteemed me as a parent—and what diſſolved that friendſhip?—you choſe to vindicate the honour of a falſe wife, and call me to the field—did I not come?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: You did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: And now where is your conſiſtency?—you would bring my daughter to the ſame degraded ſtate; you would reduce her to the level of her mother; and when an injured father aſks for ſatisfaction, you refuſe to give it him—what is this but cowardice? plain unequivocal cowardice!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Cowardice! ill as Miſs Sutherland has treated me, I never meant to raiſe my arm againſt her father:—but when you allude to the memory of her I owe ſuch obligations to, and ſay I would reduce her daughter to the ſame degraded ſtate—'tis paſt bearing—I can't endure it! and you may ſhoot me as ſoon as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Here are the weapons then—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; he is innocent, Miſs Sutherland is ſlandered!—the lady your friend ſaw enter this houſe was a very different perſon—it was the widow, indeed it was the widow!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Mrs. Dazzle?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Ay: 'tis ſhe that carries on an amour with the Captain; and though I can't produce her to prove it, I can at leaſt produce a part of her;—look, Sir—do you ſee this cloak?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Away! 'tis my unfeeling daughter's, and the ſight ſo heightens my reſentment—Come, Sir, wrongs like mine will brook no more delay, and you muſt either meet a coward's or a villain's fate—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Coward again!—Come, then—here's my ground!

sp.speaker: Worry
sp.p:
Don't think me impertinent Sir—but while you as a man of honour think it your duty to fight a duel, I as an honeſt man think it mine to prevent it!—it's the widow!
upon my ſoul, it's the widow!
sp.stage: (holding Sir HERVEY'S arm who ſtruggles to get it looſened.)

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Diſtraction!—nay then—thus—
sp.stage: (throws WORRY violently from him, who, falling againſt doors of receſs, they burſt open and Mrs. DAZZLE is diſcovered ſtanding on the pedeſtal ſurrounded by doves, &c.)

sp.speaker: Worry
sp.stage: (who has fallen at her feet, ſtill looking up in her face).
sp.p: It's the widow!—upon my ſoul it's the widow!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Amazement!—can that be Mrs. Dazzle!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No—it's a ſtatue—you ſee it's a ſtatue.

div.stage: (Mrs. DAZZLE riſes, walks quickly down the ſtage and exit.)

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Halloa! won't you take your cloak along with you? you'll want it to cover your ſins!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Hypocrite! I now view her in her true colours, and I am doomed to be the dupe of woman.—Mr. Laviſh, I ſee my friend was miſtaken, and I acknowledge I have wronged you.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Pſha!—I want no acknowledgment—if you wiſh to make me amends, ſtay and dine with me—mine is the ſyſtem of economy, and as I can't lay out money to better advantage than in entertaining an old friend, I'll give you a dinner fit for the court of Aldermen—I will, if I ſave it a thouſand ways.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p:
Excuſe me, Sir—your innocence on the preſent occaſion will not do away former injuries; nor will Mrs. Dazzle's bad conduct be an apology for my daughter's.—No!—whilſt I thought love the cauſe of her elopement, it was my duty to purſue and ſave her:—but ſince I ſee ſelf-intereſt is the motive, and that ſhe fled to avoid ſigning an inſtrument which would have ſaved me from diſgrace,
and not have injured her—I ſhall no longer condeſcend to ſeek her.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: 'Tis no ſuch thing, Sir—and if you will go to her at Mr. Miſt's houſe—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Peace!—and inſtantly attend me home, where, if the account of your own conduct prove not ſatisfactory— (WORRY attempts to ſpeak).—Nay, this is no place for explanation—go on before—Mr. Laviſh, I have the honour to wiſh you good evening!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Here's bad reckoning!—'tis well I calculate better in money matters. But what's to be done?—he ſaid ſhe was gone to Mr. Miſt's:—well! if I follow her, ſhe won't ſee me;—if I write to her, ſhe won't anſwer my letter.—Oh! ſhe's loſt!—Juliana's loſt to me for ever!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Sir, is the chaiſe to wait?

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: And yet,—if I could gain an interview—hark'ye, Frank—do you know any body at Mr. Miſt's the Manager's?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes: and ſo do you, Sir—Stopgap, who left your ſervice to go on the ſtage, is now his prompter.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: That's fortunate—I'll go to him inſtantly; and if he will but do me a favour—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That he will, if you'll bribe him: only give him ten pounds—but that you know, Sir, won't ſuit your ſyſtem of economy.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Won't it?—ten pound is no object, and I've lately made ſo many good bargains, that it's d—d hard if I can't afford to throw away an odd bank note or two.—So, come along—and if after all I do live a little beyond my income, it's no fault of mine, Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No! whoſe is it then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Whoſe!—why it is the fault of thoſe ſelfiſh harpies who make economy uſeleſs—who raiſe the price of every article:—and if Sir Hervey and other fighting gentlemen would unload their piſtols on jobbers, foreſtallers, and monopolizers, their valour would be directed to the beſt purpoſes—I might live cheap, and the country would be cleared of it's worſt enemies!

div.trailer: THE END OF THE THIRD ACT.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE—Outſide of a Theatre, and MIST'S houſe;
div.stage: LAVISH diſcovered liſtening at the door.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Gad! I hope the prompter don't want prompting: (Looking at his watch) By this 'tis ten minutes, but by my reckoning ten hours, ſince Stopgap entered this houſe with a letter for Juliana,—ſo—he comes!—he comes!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Well! what news?—have you ſeen Miſs Sutherland?

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: I have, and here—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Here's an anſwer to my letter.

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: No;—there's your letter back again—ſhe refuſed to open it, and in my preſence ordered the ſervants not to admit you into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: What! ſhe perſiſts—

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Moſt obſtinately, Sir;—but ſpite of her refuſal, make it worth my while, and I'll procure you an interview:—excuſe the hint, Sir; but if you recollect when I lived with you, you were ſo ſaving—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: So I am ſtill:—worſe and worſe,—more economical than ever;—but the hope of gaining ſuch a treaſure as Juliana!—here you rogue,—here's ten pounds on the ſtrength of it

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: So there is;—then liſten:—the play to night is the "Road to Ruin," and Mr. Prettyman, who was to have performed Goldfinch, has juſt met with an accident:—now, Sir, having no ſubſtitute, and it being too late to change the play, ſuppoſe you wait on the Manager, and offer to ſupply his place.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: I ſupply!

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Why not? at the private theatre I have ſeen you act this very part:—then an interview is certain; for Mr. Miſt's houſe adjoins the theatre, and Miſs Sutherland is now in a room cloſe to the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Is ſhe?—then I'll double Prettyman;—I'll act Goldfinch,—"that's your ſort;"—but hold, hold—don't introduce me by my own name; call me Mr. Crib, or Mr. Glib, or Mr. Squib.

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: I will; I'll call you Mr. Squib.—Huſh!—he comes.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: How! what! London Manager!—Huſband die a London Manager!—Go on, imperial Mrs. M. P.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Nay, I only tell you that Mr. Dazzle, a ſhort time previous to his deceaſe, was in treaty for a moiety of one of the London theatres; but I cannot ſay whether he lived to complete his purchaſe;—however, I ſhall write by this poſt.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
And ſo will I:—and if he did purchaſe, throne devolves to you.—Bleſs me! how majeſtic ſhe looks!—and her play.—When ſhall I hear the reſt of your moſt magnificent play?—Nay, ſpare a country monarch:—thought her great actreſs,—you
humble auther:—now you turn out manager, and ſhe worſe than a dummy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you know how to make atonement; your friend Mr. Alltrade wiſhes to marry this ungrateful girl, and as ſhe is now under your roof—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Enough—ſend for Alltrade, and then, "Good morrow, good Queen Mary."

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: I will;—I'll go write to him inſtantly;—and in return, if I do poſſeſs a London theatre, depend on't you ſhall be my ſole manager.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Right!—I'm the man to rule behind curtain.—I'm the man to accept pieces, caſt parts, and every night ſecure an overflow;—but go, thou author of the divineſt tragedy (kiſſes her hand, and Mrs. DAZZLE exit). Never ſhall it be acted though; never ſhall ſhe act her own infernal—

sp.speaker: Stopgap
sp.p: Sir!—more bad luck, Sir!—Mr. Prettyman, in trying to pull on the only pair of new boots we have in the theatre, has juſt put out his ſhoulder bone, conſequently there is nobody to act Goldfinch.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Put out ſhoulder bone!—what now!—Juſt before doors open?

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Even ſo, Sir; and we have lately made ſo many apologies—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: True; made one laſt night, two the night before: zounds! there'll be a riot; and all owing to this ungrateful ſhamming—See how it is—benefit's over—that's it—got four pounds over expences, and till that's gone, act Road to Ruin off, inſtead of on, the ſtage; but what's to be done?—found out, Stop; d—e we ſhall be found out.

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Nay: there is hope ſtill—look yonder, Sir; that gentleman is an excellent ſubſtitute; he is perfect in the part, and with your leave is ready to go on with it.—I'll introduce him—Mr. Squib, this is Mr. Miſt.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt devoted—

sp.speaker: Miſt
sp.p: Servant, my lad; ſervant—ſo, call yourſelf an actor! heh! hem!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: I do—at your ſervice, Sir.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: My ſervice!—he! he!—that's another matter—ſee you act firſt—if miſs, exit Squib—if hit, enter at half a guinea a week.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Pſha!—money's no object.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No, I've ſaved a fortune, Mr. Manager, and am ſo attached to the ſtage, that I'll not only act gratis, but when there are not expences in the houſe, I'll be bound to pay them—I will, if I ſave it a thouſand ways.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Will you?—oh that I had a whole company like him!—why you're a high fellow!

p.q: To be ſure—know the odds—hold four in hand—beat the mail—come in full ſpeed—rattle down the gateway—take care of your heads—never killed but one woman and a child in all my life—that's your ſort!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Bravo!—capital!—and no ſalary!—my dear Mr. Squib—all gratitude—all thankfulneſs—by and bye rule a London theatre—perhaps Covent Garden—Know preſent acting manager!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Mum!—kick him out, whip you in.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: That's right—kick out preſent ſtupid acting manager, and whip me in;—but come along—isn't it time to dreſs?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Not quite; juſt time to crack bottle, and draw up apology—muſt get one ready written:—much warfare lately—laſt night affronted audience myſelf.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Yourſelf! how?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Tell you:—whenever theatre's thin, always get drunk.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: In the name of heaven, why?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: He! he! he!—'cauſe it makes me ſee double—ſo going to take a peep, miſtook my way, and in dagger ſcene of Macbeth, reeled upon the ſtage, and ſtaggered up to lamps!—never ſo well received before;—delighted with applauſe, ſtood ſmiling and bowing, till Macbeth bore me off, 'midſt the ſhouting and huzzaing of a genteel, though not a numerous, audience—Expect buſtle to night in conſequence—ſo muſt knock under a little—not too much though—I'm Manager—heh!—hem!—but come along; and over bottle drink ſucceſs—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: There's no occaſion; my Goldfinch never failed—"that's your ſort!"

div.head: SCENE—A grand Saloon in Sutherland Houſe—Maſks diſcovered dancing.
div.stage: After dance, ALLTRADE dreſſed in a Domino enters with a Servant.

sp.speaker: Alltrade
sp.p:
From Mrs. Dazzle, you ſay; perhaps ſome news of Miſs Sutherland. (Opens letter and reads):
Juliana is at Mr. Miſt's, and he completely in our intereſt.—Come directly, and if Sir Hervey has given you his conſent, make him write it to
his daughter: and if he objects to that from motives of pride and delicacy, bid him write to the Manager, and entreat him to enforce his command: this ſhewn to Juliana will ſecure all;—ſhe will forfeit the legacy, and a third of my huſband's eſtate will be yours!—Excellent! and he has given me his conſent—what's here? a poſtſcript!— (Reads on): If Juliana has ſigned the bond, don't mention it to Sir Hervey—he'll expect money, and at preſent you know we have none to give him.—True: and the bond is already diſpoſed of; for if all elſe fail, that will be a grand reſource.—My compliments to Mrs. Dazzle, and I'll wait upon her preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Alltrade! my friend!—I'm glad I've found you—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Why, what agitates you?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I'm ruined—I'm expoſed—look—do you ſee thoſe maſks?
sp.stage: (pointing to two maſks in dominos who ſtand apart from the reſt).

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I do—what of them?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey
sp.p: Huſh.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Bailiffs!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Ay, an execution for a thouſand pounds, and a writ againſt my perſon for nearly the ſame ſum.—And now, in the meridian of my ſplendor, I am to meet the ſcorn of all around me; now, in the midſt of friends—but be it ſo—a gaol can't yield me leſs ſubſtantial joy than this unmeaning, artificial ſcene.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Come, come, don't rail at that which, till now, gave you happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Never.—What has it afforded me? days of diſtreſs, and nights of fever and diſgrace: borrowing one day, to pay double the next; flying to the gaming-table—ſacrificing fortune, health, honour—and for what?—to appear faſhionable; to make a falſe diſplay of wealth; and fritter away life in the ſociety of knaves I deteſt, and fools I deſpiſe.—Call you this happineſs?—No, 'tis deſperation, 'tis delirium!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Nay, be compoſed; there is ſtill a way to ſave you. You know this diſtreſs would have been avoided had your daughter ſigned the bond.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Name her not—I do not wiſh to curſe her.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
