sp.p: Well, but if ſhe will ſtill ſign—and remember our converſation this morning—on your wiſhing ſhe had a huſband to protect her, and my naming myſelf, you were pleaſed to ſay ſhe could not be in better hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I did—but what has this to do with—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Every thing.—Let the marriage take place, and I, in the character of huſband, can execute the bond myſelf. Then theſe debts will be diſcharged, and all go well again. Come, though you ſay you don't diſlike a priſon, I am too much your friend to ſee you put to the trial.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Well, I own I dread the expoſure and diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Alltrade
sp.p: Then to avoid it, write a ſtrong letter to your daughter; ſtate that her accepting my hand can alone ſave you from ruin.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I write!—I condeſcend!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p:
Nay then, to make it leſs irkſome to your feelings, write to the gentleman under whoſe
protection ſhe has placed herſelf; bid him exert his influence.—Come, ſtep with me into the next room, and I'll dictate the contents.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Well, do with me what you will; but I've but little hope.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: And I'm moſt ſanguine; and before to-night is paſt, you ſhall again enjoy this ſcene of ſplendid revelry.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: What, when I view it in its proper light?—No, my friend; ſtrip diſſipation of its robe of faſhion—ſhew it in its naked deformity—ſee it ſurrounded by its offspring, poverty, ſuicide, deſpair, and madneſs!—and who would be weak enough to purſue it?—But lead on, I obey your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: So, I have ſent the letter.—I know not why, I trembled as I wrote it; and at the thought of thus diſpoſing of my child, my foreboding heart—but I dare think no more—let the dance go on.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Oh, Sir!—ſuch news!—didn't you ſay Miſs Sutherland hadn't ſigned the bond?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I did: and but now my friend Alltrade—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p:
Your friend!—only liſten, Sir—my nephew, I'm ſorry to mention it, is an attorney; and he had the impudence to call here and aſk for a ticket for your maſked ball. Says he, I can
ſupport a character.—Says I, That's impoſſible, becauſe you've no character to ſupport.— Nay, ſays he, I'm grown honeſt ſince I ſaw you.—Oh! you are, are you? ſays I; then pray walk up; novelty at a maſquerade is every thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Pſha! what's this to me?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: You ſhall hear, Sir. I am more ſorry to mention he is Mr. Alltrade's attorney; and, by his orders, has juſt taken the bond to Miſs Sutherland, at Mr. Miſt's.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Indeed! and what was the reſult?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: What! why the moment he ſhewed her your name at the bottom of it, ſhe burſt into tears; then taking up the pen, ſhe exclaimed, Though my father is unmindful of my diſtreſſes, I can never forget his; and were it to doom me to impriſonment or death, I would execute with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: How! and did ſhe—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: She did.—And another thing—you muſt have ſigned the bond without reading it: inſtead of two years, 'tis payable on demand.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe! I'll not believe a word.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I thought ſo—I thought this would be the caſe; and therefore I perſuaded my nephew to truſt me with it— (produces bond).—Look, here is at once a proof of your friend's villainy and your daughter's virtue!—See how you have wronged her, and how he has wronged you. But the widow, ſhe is the arch agent! and talk of gentlemen of the long robe, curſe me but I believe there's more miſchief under one gown than another!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey
sp.p: Juliana Sutherland!— (weeps and lets bond fall.)—Where is ſhe, where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: How I do you mean—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I do; I mean to prove myſelf her father: the bitter ſecret long has rankled here, but now I can divulge it: and if a ſhattered heart can once more vibrate at the touch of joy, it will be when I claſp my wronged, exalted child!—Come, let us fly!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Ay, the faſter the better.—I'm ſo happy!—If Mrs. Worry were in Heaven, I couldn't be happier!—
sp.stage: (as they are going, Bailiffs in dominos advance)

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Excuſe us, Sir Hervey, we cannot part with you; and unleſs the debt is inſtantly paid, we muſt conduct you to priſon.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: To priſon!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Ay; behold my well timed puniſhment!—Now, on the brink of happineſs, I am to meet the ſure reward of deſperation and extravagance!

sp.speaker: Bailiff.
sp.p: Nay, why upbraid yourſelf, Sir Hervey? a man of your rank couldn't live ſhabbily.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: No; but I might have lived honorably; I might have lived within my income; that is the barrier no man of true honour ever paſſes: and if ſtealing on the highway be puniſhed with death, why ſhould the more refined robber, who defrauds the induſtrious tradeſman of the hard earnings by which he is to ſupport his family, why ſhould he eſcape?—Oh! let no man boaſt the proud name of gentleman, who contracts debts he cannot pay!—But I attend you—lead on—and yet—Diſtraction!—William!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p:
The worſt I had forgotten: you know not half your maſter's weakneſs, half his
villany!—not an hour ago I wrote a letter, and commanded my daughter to marry—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Whom, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: The worſt, the vileſt of mankind!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Mr. Alltrade?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Yes; I, her father, in return for all her fondneſs and affection, commanded her to link herſelf to infamy, diſhonour!—But is it yet too late to ſave her?—will ſhe not be merciful?—oh! will ſhe not diſobey me?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: No, ſhe's ſo affectionate, that the moment ſhe reads the letter—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Ay, but perhaps ſhe has not yet received it.—Go, loſe not a moment; 'tis directed to the gentleman at whoſe houſe ſhe now reſides.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I'll go; I'll do all I can to ſave her: and, in the mean time, pray keep up your ſpirits, Sir: indeed, indeed you deſerve a better fate.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: No, I deſerve it all!—think what I am, and what I might have been!—now an outcaſt and a beggar, dragged from my home, and plunged into a priſon!—and, but for faſhion and its errors, that houſe had been a heaven!—But my child!— go—be ſwifter than the letter—ſave her from ſeeing what will make her curſe me; and, whilſt it dooms her to eternal miſery, will be an everlaſting evidence of my diſgrace!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: 'Tis he! 'tis Alltrade! now for it!—now if Sir Hervey has but conſented to the marriage.— (Here LAVISH opens door in back ſcene, and is coming out; but ſeeing Mrs. DAZZLE ſtops and liſtens). Oh, I'm ſo anxious.— (Enter ALLTRADE.)—Well! what ſucceſs? will the match take place?—ſhall I inherit my huſband's eſtate?

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: You will! this letter from Sir Hervey to Mr. Miſt will explain and ſecure every thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Let me ſee— (takes letter and reads): To Mr. Miſt.—Sir, My daughter having placed herſelf under your protection, I am induced to think you have an influence over her, though her father has none; therefore let me entreat you to exert it, by perſuading her to accept the hand of my friend Mr. Alltrade, and aſſure her that her marriage with that gentleman can alone ſave me from ruin, or lead to the reconciliation, ſhe has ſo long pretended to wiſh for.—HERVEY SUTHERLAND.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: There! ſhe's too dutiful to refuſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs Dazzle.
sp.p: Oh, the thought of ſaving him from ruin would of itſelf induce her to conſent; but the hope of a reconciliation alſo!—delightful! charming! Go, take the letter to Mr. Miſt, and bid him come and ſhew it Juliana directly.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: And, d'ye hear; then away to a parſon: in the mean time I'll get a licence, and in leſs than half an hour the marriage ſhall take place in this very room.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Madam, here's a Mr. Worry—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Don't admit him; remember you have orders to admit nobody.— (Servant exit.) Away! diſpatch, my friend; and now Miſs Juliana, I defy you! neither your father nor your lover, no, not even the economical Captian, can ſave his darling treaſure now.

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: Can't he? he'll try a thouſand ways though.—'Sdeath! no ſooner reconciled to Juliana—no ſooner convinced her of my truth and affection, than I'm to ſee her—If ſhe reads the letter; all's over! for her laſt words were, I will marry no man, but the one my father ſelects for me.—and now, when his ruin and a reconciliation depend on her conſenting—plague on't! I could play the fool and weep: yes, I'm no niggard here! (putting his hand to his heart)—and if I can purchaſe her ſafety even at the loſs of my life, I ſhall reckon it the beſt bargain I ever made.

sp.speaker: Miſt
sp.p: Very well, I'll deliver letter—I'll make widow amends.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Here he comes, and in his poſſeſſion what will for ever ruin me and Juliana; nay, alſo Sir Hervey:—I'm ſure he's under ſome dreadful error; and if I can ſave his daughter at this moment, my triumph will be ten times greater than in fighting him;—yes, that I ſhall call honourable ſatisfaction. What can I deviſe?—ſee the letter ſhe ſhall not! and there is no way to prevent it but by getting this credulous old manager out of the room. Let me ſee—I have it!—he talked of a riot in his theatre!—it will do! it will do!

sp.speaker: Miſt
sp.p: So, here's Sir Hervey's letter; and I'm to ſhew it Miſs Sutherland; and enforce marriage, and—u.u-up! (Hiccuping): methinks I ſee double again—methinks—no—no I'm not on ſtage now, 'cauſe hear no applauſe: drunk or ſober, ſure to encourage ſuch a promiſing young actor.

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: Drunk too!—better and better!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: He! he! he!—wonder how Mr. Squib—how Mr. No Salary's going on?—ſays he, I'm a private actor!—Hem, ſays I, more private the better:—hope they accept him though; hope they let him double Prettyman; if not, here's ſuch an apology! (pulling out a paper, and putting it back again)—ſuch a beautiful, witty compoſition; but hold:—now to ſee Miſs Sutherland!

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: And now to prevent you. (Aſide.)—Oh, Sir, I was juſt going for you: the riot is begun,—the whole theatre is in an uproar.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Devil! what!—want Prettyman?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No, they want you—Tell you how it was—Stopgap went on, and claimed their uſual indulgence—on which a little tiger-faced fellow exclaimed from the pit, We'll bear it no longer!— if the Manager will conſtantly make apologies, play the beſt parts, act his own farces, get drunk, and reel upon the ſtage, why the theatre is a nuiſance!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: A nuiſance!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p:
Ay: And either let him come and account for his conduct, or let us treat it as a nuiſance:—let
us pull it down!—He was ſtrongly ſupported; and I left the whole houſe calling "Manager! Manager!"—ſo go—go directly

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: I go! I account!—to whom:—to a five pound houſe!—to a tiger-faced gentleman, and a dozen more ungrateful, taſteleſs ſcoundrels—I!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Taſteleſs!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Yes: haven't I done every thing!—turn'd author, actor, engaged Harlequin, and half ruined myſelf to pleaſe 'em?—and now—look 'ye, Mr. Squib, here's my apology— (taking paper out of his pocket):—if that will ſatisfy 'em, let Stop read it—if not, and they ſtill abuſe me as acting manager, ſee how they like me in another character—acting magiſtrate!—Damme! myſelf and two conſtables 'll take the whole houſe!

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.stage: (looking at the paper in MIST's hand).
sp.p: By heaven, he has miſtaken!—'tis Sir Hervey's letter! (aſide).—Yes! that will do: give me that apology, and I'll anſwer for every body being ſatisfied—nay! there's no time for heſitation—they abſolutely threatened to make you go down on your knees.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: His knees!—a Manager on his knees!—that for 'em!
sp.stage: (ſnapping his fingers and turning away from LAVISH).

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Nay; the apology—'tis, 'tis Sir Hervey's hand! (aſide).—Give me the apology.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: That for 'em! won't—won't condeſcend to let 'em hear even apology now.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No!—'Sdeath: I've marr'd every thing.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
No: ſoon manage London audience, and not even to them—but they know better—and were I before 'em at this moment—inſtead of
aſking for apology—inſtead of approving this mean cowardly piece of writing, they'd applaud me for deſtroying it—they would!—ſo there!—preſerved my character both as man and as Manager!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: You have! and Juliana's preſerved and I'm preſerved!— (Enter Mrs. DAZZLE.)— Here am I, widow—been to Hatchet's—beſpoke wedding coach—all flaſh—damn the expence—that's your ſort.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: You here, Sir!—Mr. Miſt, have you ſhewn Miſs Sutherland her father's letter?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: No; and can't ſtay to do it now—muſt go quell riot—muſt talk to tiger-fac'd gentleman—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.p: Nay: if you wiſh to make me amends, I inſiſt you do it inſtantly, and let me be eye witneſs of his mortification and her deſpair—Come forth, Miſs Juliana!— (opens door in back ſcene, and leads out JULIANA).—Now, Mr. Miſt, where is Sir Hervey's letter?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Here

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Then read it, and ſecure my triumph.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: I will—hem! (Reads).— Ladies and Gentlemen, the diſagreeable dilemma to which I am reduced—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.p: Why, you miſtake—let me read.— (Reads)— Ladies and Gentlemen, the diſagreeable dilemma to which I am reduced— why what's this paper?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: An apology—that I'm ready to offer you, though not audience—I'm very ſorry, but can't ſtay to explain now—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing!—why, what's become of Sir Hervey's letter?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: What I (points to the tern letter),—You take the hint—muſt go to tiger faced gentleman—you take the hint.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: What can he mean!—I'll follow him, and have the matter explained inſtantly—and don't fancy to eſcape, Miſs Juliana; for Sir Hervey ſhall come himſelf and enforce his conſent; and if that fails,—the bond—look to the bond—Oh, you may ſmile, Sir (to LAVISH), but you'll find revenge is ſtill in my power.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: You hear, Miſs Sutherland; and to avoid the danger with which you are threatened take my advice and be beforehand with them.—Fly to your father—throw yourſelf at his feet—entreat his protection—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: I will; there is no other hope—go where I will, they ſtill purſue and perſecute me.—Yes! I'll to my father!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Come then—allow me to conduct you—and if I too throw myſelf at his feet, and he no longer thinks me his enemy—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Alas! even then, Mr. Laviſh—conſider. I am ſo deſtitute of every hope of fortune—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Fortune! oh, if that's all the difficulty, it's only to leſſen our expences—to live on a narrow ſcale:—inſtead of a houſe in Groſvenor-ſquare, we muſt be content with one in Groſvenor-ſtreet:—inſtead of four horſes, we muſt drive only a pair:—and to avoid gaming and giving great entertainments, we muſt go every night to the play or the opera.—But come—and though thus far I ſhall ſtint you, my dear Juliana, in every other reſpect I'll indulge you to the laſt ſhilling—I will, if I ſave it a thouſand ways!

div.trailer: THE END OF THE FOURTH ACT.

div.head: SCENE—The Court-yard of a Priſon, Wall and great Gates in back Scene; on each Side Apartments in the Priſon, and O. P. Steps leading up to a Door.—Moonlight.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Nay, let me entreat you, Sir, retire to your chamber!—you forget you are in a priſon.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: But are you ſure my daughter is not Alltrade's wife?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I am, Sir! and that ſhe owes her deliverance to the generous exertions of Captain Laviſh. (Loud knocking at gate.)—There—you hear, Sir!—now pray, pray retire.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Well! conduct me; and in the morning wait on Captain Laviſh, and expreſs my warmeſt gratitude.—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Aye, that I will, Sir! and make every inquiry after Miſs Sutherland:— but now, Sir! (Loud knocking again).—Bleſs me! this is a moſt unconſcionable ſort of place! —neither let people in or out!—'tis deviliſh hard:—I dare ſay the gentleman has as much right to be here as any body!—This way, Sir, this way!
sp.stage: (Sir HERVEY and WORRY aſcend ſteps, and exeunt.)

div.stage: (Gates are opened, and enter JULIANA and two Bailiffs.)

sp.speaker: Firſt Bailiff.
sp.p: Come, come!—now all's ſafe!—though if we had'nt contrived to ſeparate her from Captain Laviſh by means of a forged letter—

sp.speaker: Second Bailiff.
sp.p: Ay, that was my planning!—ſo here you are, Miſs! arreſted on your bond for five thouſand pounds;—and you know Mr. Alltrade's terms!—either ſign a contract of marriage—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: That I never will.

sp.speaker: Firſt Bailiff.
sp.p: Good night then.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Stay!—ſpare me but a moment!—unuſed to this ſcene of terror and diſtreſs, unleſs ſome friendly hand is ſtretched to ſave me, I muſt e'en fall and periſh here!—Oh, I am faint! quite—quite ſick at heart.

sp.speaker: Second Bailiff.
sp.p: You'd better ſign the contract then.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Never! never! (Bailiffs exeunt).—They're gone:—now, Juliana, ſummon all your courage!—alone,—unprotected! in the worſt place, amongſt the worſt ſociety; ſeparated from the man you love, deſerted by the father you revere, and ſo deprived of every hope of aid, that, ſhould you linger on for years, here, here at laſt muſt be your grave! (Shouting and laughing without.)—Heavens! what noiſe is that?—a ſet of the moſt needy and moſt deſperate! (Stamping:) Again!—they come this way—and I am left to be the victim of their brutality!—I can't ſupport it!—I faint with terror!—Oh, help! help! (Falls at the foot of the ſteps).

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Surely I heard a woman's voice,—and ſeemingly in much diſtreſs!—'tis ſo!—poor wretch!—ſhe ſcarcely breathes:—Within there! (Re-enter Worry:)—give your aſſiſtance! help me to raiſe this poor unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I will, I will! (They raiſe JULIANA, who remains in a lifeleſs ſtate).—Merciful powers!
sp.stage: (ſeeing her face, ſtarting, and moving away).

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Ha! what alarms you?—do you know her?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: I do!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Who is it?—what brings her here? ſpeak!—has ſhe no friends? no relations?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Yes:—ſhe has a father!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Barbarian!—could he not prevent—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: He could, but—aſk your own heart! mine would burſt to ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Ay, your much wronged daughter!—who evidently has been brought here on the bond ſhe ſigned to ſave you!—but don't—don't be unhappy, Sir! I'll go directly for aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Fly! begone! (WORRY exit.—JULIANA remains ſtill lifeleſs in Sir HERVEY'S arms:)—can I behold all this, and live?—Poor girl!—the very features of—Oh, God! Oh, God!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Give me air!—So; I am much, much better.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Indeed!—I am glad, cordially glad: ha! ha! (weeping)—you've ſaved my life!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Your life!—ſuch kindneſs from a ſtranger!—Oh! in this place I little thought to find a friend!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: And do you call me friend!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: I hope I may! you ſeem to take an intereſt in my ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: I do—I do! and well I know the author of them all!—too well I know the father that has cauſed them.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: My father! do you know my father?—Oh, when you ſee him, don't tell him you found me in priſon! that would afflict him, and it would double my miſery to add to his!—don't—pray don't tell him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Why not?—why feel for him who never felt for you! has he not from your infancy deſerted you?—has he not ſhut his doors againſt you? and, inſtead of being your friend and protector, has he not proved himſelf your enemy—your perſecutor?

sp.speaker: Juliana
sp.p: Well! if he has, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Did he not thwart you in your affections,—tear you from the man you love, and command you to marry him you hate?—and after theſe accumulated injuries, and you had involved yourſelf to ſupport him, what was his return? ingratitude! what was your inheritance? poverty! —what has been your reward? a priſon!—Oh, villain! villain!—worſt of villains!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Villain!—hold your unlicenſed tongue. Villain!—who are you that dare thus accuſe my father?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p:
A libertine; whoſe diſſipation drove his wife into ſuch ſcenes of error and remorſe that ſhe died of a broken heart!—an outcaſt! who, not content with that, would have reduced his daughter to the ſame unhappy fate!—a wretch! who, abandoned her not for her own conduct, but her mother's!—who brought her to a priſon!—who
ſees her there without the hope of ſaving her!—or, to ſum up all in one emphatic word—to give the aggregate of complicated infamy—I am your father!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Ay, look at me!—view me well—do you not ſhudder at the hideous ſight? will you not curſe—avoid me as a peſtilence?—a fiend!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: No: I will cling to you!—thus grow for ever round you! (throwing herſelf into his arms).—My father! my dear, dear father!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Juliana, be merciful!—load me with reproaches—this kindneſs will deſtroy me!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Reproach you!—what, at the moment I have ſound you?—no: let me but be near you, and I will bleſs the hour that brought me to this place!—for it has given me the utmoſt wiſhes of my ſoul—it has reſtored to me a parent!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: There! 'tis as I expected; they are reconciled—look! have you the heart to interrupt their joy?

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Sir Hervey, I have no wiſh but to give you both liberty; and if you will fulfil your promiſe, by perſuading Miſs Sutherland to accept my hand—nay: why frown?—you ſee I come as a friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Friend! away—I'm weary of the very word.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: What! weary of friendſhip, Sir Hervey!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p:
Ay, Sir; time was, when friendſhip wore a bold and open aſpect, and as it ſpoke
it acted: but now 'tis maſked; and underneath it lurks all modern villany. Who betrayed my wife? a friend!—who belied my child? a friend!—who immured her in a gaol, and if ſhe does not proſtitute her hand and heart, will ſee her periſh there—who, but my friend!—Can my enemy thus injure me?—No; in him I place no confidence or truſt; and henceforth let me rather meet a thouſand foes than the deſigning arts of one falſe friend.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Well, as you pleaſe— (Enter LAVISH behind)—here is Miſs Sutherland's diſcharge; but ſince you don't chooſe to accede to my propoſals, good night
sp.stage: (ſhewing diſcharge, and putting it up again).

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Nay, let me entreat you, Mr. Alltrade.

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: And let me entreat you, Mr. Alltrade.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: No, I can be obſtinate in my turn—good night.

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: Then let me entreat you, Mr. Alltrade—nay, don't think to eſcape, Sir—Bleſs you! you are quite miſtaken; Mr. Alltrade's the moſt kind, obliging—The diſcharge—give me the diſcharge, you ſcoundrel—or elſe, Newmarket in the firſt place (ſhaking his cane), and high life in the ſecond

sp.speaker: Alltrade
sp.p: Well, Sir—ſince you inſiſt, Sir—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: I do; and be quick—diſpatch— (ALLTRADE gives LAVISH a paper). Oh, this is the very thing I ſuppoſe— (begins reading it)— By this my laſt will, I Jeremiah Dazzle give and bequeath—

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Stop, ſtop—that's the wrong paper—here, here's the diſcharge.

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.stage: (takes it and puts it into his pocket).
sp.p: Very well—a good economiſt pockets every thing— (Reads on): all the property of which I die poſſeſſed, unto that moſt amiable—Juliana Sutherland.—Amazement! (Sir HERVEY, JULIANA, and LAVISH all look at each other with aſtoniſhment, and during pauſe ALLTRADE exit.) There—you take care of that, Sir Hervey, whilſt I take care of Mr.— (turns round and finds ALLTRADE gone)—what! gone!—I'll follow him—I'll—but no—we've got all we want from him—and ſo, 'ſpite of our former animoſities, Sir Hervey, allow me to congratulate you.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey
sp.p: No, Sir; my hopes are vaniſhed, I find here the fortune is conditional:—if my daughter marries, it devolves to Mrs. Dazzle.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: If ſhe marries?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Ay, Sir!—while ſhe remains ſingle, ſhe may roll in affluence, and I be reſtored to all my former ſplendor;—but will that give either of us conſolation? No; my own ſad example has taught me the reverſe; and therefore, mark me, Juliana—I wiſh to make atonement, to give you fixed, unceaſing happineſs;—and having proved myſelf unfit to guard ſo dear a charge,—let him who beſt deſerves, let him protect you!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Him!—whom, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey
sp.p:
Him!—Accept her, Mr. Laviſh,—take her as the beſt recompence for all the wrongs I've done you.—Nay, I know the penalty:—I know, by marrying you ſhe forfeits this eſtate; and for your ſake I wiſh it had accompanied her; but for my own!—at laſt
I've acted as a parent ought, and though theſe gates are ever ſhut againſt me, I know my daughter's happy, and that thought will give what wealth can never purchaſe;—a quiet conſcience and unbròken reſt.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Sir Hervey, you have acted nobly—but—

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: But what?—You are ſufficiently affluent to maintain her.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No; there's the curſe on't: I thought I had ſaved a fortune;—but juſt now, when I heard of your mutual diſtreſs, and drew bills on my ſteward and my banker, they refuſed payment;—to my aſtoniſhment they ſaid I hadn't a ſhilling!—there you ſee, there's the end of my economy!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: And you'd have paid my debts—you'd have releaſed your enemy?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Ay, that I would, if I'd ſaved it a thouſand ways;—but to marry on ſuch conditions!—No—I'll die firſt.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: And ſo will I; and hard as it is, here let us ſeparate, Mr. Laviſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Never!—never ſhall you be divided!—and though we can expect no liberality from Mrs. Dazzle, yet under all the circumſtances ſhe may be induced to compromiſe—perhaps allow us a moiety, or a third.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Ay, or any thing,—if ſhe'll only allow us two hundred a-year, with my management I'll be bound we'll all live comfortably;—I'll go make her propoſals inſtantly, and don't fear my ſucceſs;—for at a bargain,—never was ſuch a fellow at making a bargain.

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: Adieu, Mr. Laviſh; pray Heaven you may ſucceed!

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: So ſay I: and if ſhe don't come to an amicable adjuſtment, conteſt the will, and employ my nephew to file a bill in Chancery againſt her.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No, that will never do: rather give up the whole property than go to law.—Come, that's good economy, or the devil's in it.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Come, Juliana, in my apartments we'll wait his return.— (To WORRY): You alſo, faithful, conſtant friend!

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: How ſhall I thank you? how repay—

sp.speaker: Worry.
sp.p: Repay!—Look! are you not reconciled? Isn't that repaying me?—Oh! I am the happieſt fellow living!—No—I forgot Mrs. Worry.

div.head: SCENE—A Street in the Town.
div.stage: Enter ALLTRADE, Mrs. DAZZLE, and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Don't talk to me, Sir.—The will diſcovered!

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I tell you it was no fault of mine, and my lyfe on't Miſs Sutherland will marry the Captain, and ſtill forfeit the bequeſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: She marry! ſhe marry! nonſenſe! Haven't I this inſtant ſeen the faithleſs Captain, and isn't it exactly as I ſuſpected?—Take my word for it, Juliana will keep the eſtate and her lover too.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: How! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p:
Mean? that the Captain never thought of making her his wife; and the father, to gain his liberty and five thouſand a-year, will be
unprincipled enough to conſent to his daughter's diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: Oh, I underſtand now:—live together without marrying.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Ay; Mr. Laviſh not only didn't deny the infamous ſcheme, but abſolutely offered me two hundred a-year if I'd give up all claim under my huſband's will; if not, he ſaid he and Juliana would go to Italy, and live on the profits. What ſhall I do?—deprived of my huſband's eſtate, I'm abſolutely pennyleſs.

sp.speaker: Alltrade.
sp.p: I know; and you ſee they are decided; therefore, why heſitate?—two hundred a-year is certainly better than nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: True; and as I have no other hope,—John, go to Mr. Laviſh, ſay I accede to his propoſals, and if he'll bring an agreement to my houſe, I'll ſign directly. (Servant exit.) Oh! that it ſhould come to this;—but I'll expoſe them—I'll—

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: From Mr. Miſt, Madam;—it is of the utmoſt conſequence, and requires an immediate anſwer

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Yes, Madam;—he has this moment received poſitive information, that Mr. Dazzle died poſſeſſed of half a London theatre; and as you are his widow, Madam—but the letter will explain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.p:
Majeſtic Mrs. M. P.—only time to ſay, forget paſt bad management—accept hand and fortune; we'll inſtantly act
Benedict and Beatrice.—Doors to be opened at eight, and performance begin preciſely at nine, Vivant Rex et Regina!—P.M.—. N. B. Would have waited on you in perſon, but Harlequin and ſlow waggon are juſt arrived. Delightful! glorious!—now I am rich enough to defy the Captain and his aſſociates:—My compliments to Mr. Miſt, I'll wait upon him inſtantly, and the ſooner the marriage takes place, the happier it will make me. (STOPGAP exit.)—Come, Mr. Alltrade, you ſhall ſhare my good fortune, and when the Captain brings the agreement, how I ſhall laugh at him; I now deſpiſe, as much as I once loved him.

div.head: SCENE—Inſide of a Theatre.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Forfeit 'em,—I'll forfeit 'em.—Harlequin arrived!—firſt call new pantomime, and not an actor come to rehearſal;—vagabonds!—all envy—all jealouſy;—dread his immortal powers, and want to knock him up;—won't do though—not eaſily put out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: Joy! I give you joy, Sir; Mrs. Dazzle conſents.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: What! doors opened at eight.

sp.speaker: Stop.
sp.p: Ay, and performance begin at nine.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: And no money returned after curtain's drawn up!—tol de roll, toll, loll:—I'm a real London Manager!—that, (ſnapping his fingers,) that for this half or rather no priced toy-ſhop:—but where is ſhe?—where's the imperial Mrs. M. P.

sp.speaker: Stopgap.
sp.p: She'll be here directly, and Mr. Squib alſo: I met him in the ſtreet, and on my telling him you were about to marry Mrs. Dazzle for the ſake of her theatrical property, he ſaid you were groſsly impoſed upon, and that he'd wait upon you, and explain the matter inſtantly:—and ſee, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: He explain! pſha! what does he know about— (Enter LAVISH)—Excuſe me, Mr. Squib, can't talk to ſtrollers now; I'm real—a Royal London Manager.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: So am I; I'm a real Royal London Manager.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: You!—good, very good; and you've got old Dazzle's ſhare, ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Yes, and I've got old Dazzle's ſhare, ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Better and better!—in right of the heireſs too?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Yes, in right of the heireſs too.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: What, you mean to marry the widow?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No, damn me if I do; and if I did, that wouldn't help me.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No; the theatre is not hers, it belongs to Miſs Sutherland— (producing will):—here it is under old Dazzle's hand: here's another apology, read it, and then once more— Ladies and Gentlemen, the diſagreeable dilemma to which I am reduced—ha! ha! there's a Manager for you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.p: Where is my life, my lord, my huſband?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: There, you read the will, while I talk to the heireſs.— (MIST and STOPGAP retire up the ſtage with the will, Mrs. DAZZLE enters.)—So, widow, here's the agreement.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Then you may take it back again; I ſhan't ſign it.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: No; my marriage with Mr. Miſt makes me ſufficiently rich and independent to refuſe the paltry offer; and I can now ſhew the world that I'm above being a party in ſo infamous a tranſaction! ſo I wiſh you a pleaſant tour to Italy, good Signor Laviſhini.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: You're wrong! it's a mighty pretty income:—I'd be bound to keep a carriage on two hundred a-year.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Very likely: but you have your anſwer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stopgap
sp.p: Yes: Miſs Sutherland's heireſs!—Mr. Squib Manager.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: And I'm dethroned:—exit Miſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Look! there's my dear intended! Now, Sir, ſee me take poſſeſſion of his hand and ate.—Oh, Mr. Miſt!

sp.speaker: Stopgap
sp.p: I have a thought, Sir! rhaps Miſs Sutherland may wiſh to ſell—and through Mr. Squib's intereſt, and by ſecuring him the deputyſhip—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: I may get purchaſe! well prompted, Stop—we'll pay court to new monarch;—now mind, one of beſt benefit bows.—
sp.stage: (They put themſelves in bowing attitudes and advance towards Mrs. DAZZLE.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Delightful man!—with what awe he approaches me!—you ſee, Signor—you ſee!
sp.stage: (MIST and STOPGAP paſs by Mrs. DAZZLE and come cloſe to LAVISH.)

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Royal Mr. Squib—ſee your authority, and humbly—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle
sp.p: Why, Mr. Miſt, I'm on this ſide.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: I know! but I am on the other ſide: a good Manager always goes with the ruling party:—any reparation to you or the heireſs, Mr. Squib! would ſhe chooſe the freedom? or you take a benefit?—play myſelf, and give you firſt night of new pantomime.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: You ſee, Signora, you ſee!—why if you're in earneſt, Mr. Miſt, Miſs Sutherland's father is in priſon, and as this Will gives him no ready money—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: I take—what's the debt?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: A trifle!—but a thouſand pounds, which in the courſe of a month I can ſave and repay you!—or if that ſecurity don't content you, you ſhall have a mortgage on the theatre.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: That's it; that's the beſt ſecurity on earth! far better than meadows and corn fields!—people will go without bread, but, bleſs 'em! never without plays!—Come along, Stop—priſon only next door—gaoler take my word:—re enter with Sir Hervey inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Why, are you mad, Sir?—will you again diſappoint and deceive me?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Deceive you!—hem!—who concealed will?—paſſed off for Manager, and turns out only author?—who under falſe pretences would have pocketed all my ſcenes, dreſſes, and decorations?—No, no—you deceived me; and therefore, Mary, once more I follow thee! and ſo, Good morrow, good Queen Elizabeth!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Barbarian! Savage!—this is the third time he has made a dupe of me, Mr. Laviſh! (Burſts into tears).—I'll ſign the agreement, Mr. Laviſh!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Excuſe me!—I'm above being a party in ſo infamous a tranſaction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Nay: when you conſider the ſmallneſs of the ſum, and that I bind myſelf to give up all claim under my huſband's will:—

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Why, that's true; and ſeriouſly ſpeaking two hundred a-year is no object; and therefore, I'll indulge you?—ſign directly, and I'll indulge you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: The ſooner the better!—I long to be out of the monſter's houſe!—here's pen and ink.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: And here's the agreement!

div.stage: Enter MIST, Sir HERVEY, and JULIANA.

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Take care—conſider you're a new performer, Sir Hervey—you alſo, Miſs M. P. mind the traps.

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how to expreſs my thanks or my aſtoniſhment.

sp.speaker: Laviſh
sp.p: Huzza! Sir Hervey, I give you joy—Miſs Sutherland, I give you joy—here it is, ſigned and ſealed.—Mrs. Dazzle generouſly takes two hundred a-year, and gives up all claim under her huſband's will—there! there's a bargain maker for you!

sp.speaker: Sir Hervey.
sp.p: Is this true, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: True!—you know I've been tricked into it.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: You have—you trick'd yourſelf into it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: Myſelf!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p:
Ay! you would be indulged; and as here is now no longer any bar to our union, with
this lady's (taking JULIANA's hand) and her father's leave allow me to introduce you to Mrs. Laviſh elect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: How! your wife!

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Ay; you thought I'd call her by another name; but I am ſtill old faſhioned enough to think the word "wife," heightens happineſs and gives a zeſt to love!— (Mrs. DAZZLE is going to ſpeak)—Nay, don't blame me!—you have to thank yourſelf for the whole tranſaction; and when any body makes falſe charges, I hope I ſhall be always too good an economiſt not to make them pay for them.

sp.speaker: Miſt
sp.p: You take the hint!—you take the hint!

sp.speaker: Mrs Dazzle.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhall go wild—I—

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Gently—you'll be down the trap.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dazzle.
sp.p: So, Miſs, you mean to allow me only this paltry—

sp.speaker: Juliana.
sp.p: No, Madam!—with my huſband's permiſſion the annuity ſhall be doubled.—The widow of my benefactor muſt be more amply provided for.

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Certainly!—I can ſave it a thouſand ways!—And now, Mr. Miſt, as we ſhall certainly diſpoſe of our theatrical property, you ſhall be the purchaſer—Only mind, I make the bargain—never was ſuch a fellow at making bargains!

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p: Name your own terms—only let me be London Manager!—Oh, for the opening!—Oh, for the firſt night!—After Hamlet, what an addreſs will I make to them?

sp.speaker: Laviſh.
sp.p: Addreſs! why what will you ſay?

sp.speaker: Miſt.
sp.p:
Tell you— Ladies and Gentlemen—on the part of the company in general, and myſelf
as proprietor, author, actor, and manager in particular—confeſs faults—acknowledge obligations—and humbly entreat your uſual candour and indulgence.—Then getting nearer the lamps— Ladies and Gentlemen, to-morrow and following evening, with your permiſſion, this play will be repeated!

div.head: EPILOGUE, WRITTEN BY GEORGE COLMAN, ESQ.

sp.stage: Spoken by Mr. FAWCETT in the Character of MIST.

lg.l: A London Manager of high degree,
I, Peter Miſt, now enter here O. P.;
My country playhouſe, e'er I came to town
Almoſt knock'd up, has been in lots knock'd down.
A ſturdy farmer bought the walls:—why then,
What was a barn will be a barn again.
Corn on the ſtage, not mummers will be ſeen;
And oats be threſh'd where actors ſhould have been;
Wheat ſtrew the boards where erſt did heroes tread,
To make—what heroes never made there—bread.
Stage-ſtruck, but hen-peck'd, honeſt Juſtice Dunder
Has all my clouds,—his lady has my thunder.
Dick Drench, the ſnug apothecary, means
To give a private play, ſo buys my ſcenes:
Drench, "ſmelling of the ſhop," and idem ſemper,
Could not reſiſt ſcenes painted in diſtemper.
The Member for the town bought all my coats;
There he was wiſe—for I command two votes;
And playhouſe coats (again he ſhew'd diſcerning)
Will ſuit a Member, for they're us'd to turning.
My wigs the women quarrell'd for, ſweet ſouls!
My daggers ſtuck in ſelling; but my bowls
Mine hoſt of the Red Lion clapp'd his eyes on,
And bought 'em, as I did, to ſerve up poiſon.
Thus all my country ſtock, as Shakſpeare ſays,
"My cloud-capt towers, my gorgeous palaces,
"Yea, my great globe," (the barn,) ſo much involv'd,
And "all it did inherit, have diſſolv'd."
But if ſome future Manager ſhould take
My "ſolemn temple," which I now forſake;
My "fabric of a viſion," he will find
That I have left a curſed "wreck behind."
Here then I come, by rural ſchemes half undone,
But country ſtumps appear new brooms in London.
Egad I'll ſweep all clean—look to't—ne'er doubt me—
A London Manager, I'll lay about me;
And, as a ſample, you ſhall hear my hints,
To be inſerted in to-morrow's prints:
"A five act play laſt night was repreſented,
"By an amazing Dramatiſt invented!
"Author's and Actors' merits were immenſe,
"And Fawcett e'en ſurpaſs'd his uſual excellence!
"Great care 'tis plain was taken in rehearſal;
"And"—may I add with truth?—"applauſe was "univerſal."
